entry.title: I Built LangChain-lite for ABAP, and Solved the Enterprise AI Cold Start Problem
entry.content:
Why enterprise AI projects fail at the "last mile"

AGI has been achieved!* Now your ABAP-Native AI can reach enterprise data where it lives.

Hello! üëã It's Alice again, and I've spent the last 1.5 years building what I wish had existed when I started my AI journey: a complete LLM orchestration framework that lives entirely within SAP.

TL;DR:

  • GitHub: oisee/zllm (releasing incrementally - link in first comment)
  • Problem: Enterprise AI projects die in "integration hell" between proof-of-concept and production
  • Solution: Native ABAP AI orchestration - no Python, no APIs, no middleware
  • Result: Build production AI workflows in hours, not months

Remember my previous posts?

  • üîçZVDB brought vector search to ABAP

  • üìèPREDICTOKEN eliminated expensive tokenizer calls

  • üîóThe OData-MCP bridge connected 15,000+ enterprise services to AI

 

Those were puzzle pieces; ZLLM is the complete picture.

The "Last Mile" Problem Nobody Talks About

Your AI proof-of-concept is brilliant. The CEO is excited. Then someone asks:

"When can we connect this to our actual SAP system?"

Traditional Answer: "We need APIs, data pipelines, authentication, environments, deployments, monitoring..."

Six months later: Still in integration hell. üíÄ

ZLLM Answer: "It's already connected." ‚ú®

What Enterprise AI Actually Looks Like

This is what you can build today, in pure ABAP, with zero external dependencies:

" Complete customer intelligence pipeline
DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_extract_customer_data )    
  ( lo_analyze_behavior_patterns )
  ( lo_identify_upsell_opportunities )
  ( lo_generate_action_plan )     
  ( lo_update_crm_notes )         
) ).

DATA(lr_result) = lo_flow->exec( REF #( lv_customer_id ) ).

Time to production: Hours External systems involved: Zero** Integration code: Zero

The Template Engine That Understands Your Data

Here's where ZLLM gets magical - watch this:

" Your nested ABAP structure
DATA: BEGIN OF ls_order,
        customer TYPE BEGIN OF customer_struct,
          name TYPE string,
          vip_status TYPE abap_bool,
        END OF customer,
        items TYPE TABLE OF order_item,
      END OF ls_order.

" Template that just works
DATA(lo_pattern) = zcl_llm_00_pat=>new(
  'Customer {T-CUSTOMER-NAME} (VIP: {T-CUSTOMER-VIP_STATUS}) ' &&
  'ordered {T-ITEMS-PRODUCT_NAME} for ${T-ITEMS-PRICE}'
).

DATA(lv_prompt) = lo_pattern->apply( REF #( ls_order ) ).

The template engine automatically:

 

  • ‚úÖNavigates deep structure hierarchies
  • ‚úÖIterates over internal tables
  • ‚úÖConverts complex data to JSON when needed
  • ‚úÖHandles NULL values gracefully

 

No JSON glue code. No data mapping. No field-by-field extraction. It just works.

 

Lazy Execution: The Enterprise Performance Secret

Traditional AI workflows block everything:

# Traditional synchronous hell
result1 = llm.call(prompt1)          # Wait 3 seconds
result2 = llm.call(prompt2)          # Wait 3 seconds 
result3 = llm.call(prompt3)          # Wait 3 seconds
# Total: 9 seconds of blocking execution

ZLLM uses lazy execution for real performance:

" Start all operations immediately (non-blocking)
DATA(lo_result1) = lo_step1->start( ir_input ).
DATA(lo_result2) = lo_step2->start( ir_input ).
DATA(lo_result3) = lo_step3->start( ir_input ).

" Collect results when ready
DATA(lr_final1) = lo_result1->collect( ).  " ~3 seconds total

 

The Security Story Enterprise Can Actually Use

ZLLM includes security foundations that scale to enterprise requirements:

At Rest:

" Default: Symmetric XOR with seed (fine for PoC/development)
SET PARAMETER ID 'ZLLM_CODEC' FIELD '12345'.

" Production: Implement your codec interface
DATA(lo_enterprise_codec) = zcl_your_enterprise_codec=>new( ).

At Runtime:

" Inherits SAP's proven security model
" If user can't access data in GUI, they can't access via AI
" No new security surface area

Bottom Line: ZLLM starts secure enough for development and PoCs, with clear paths to enterprise-grade security when you need it.

Real Demo: 30-Second Customer Intelligence

METHOD generate_customer_intelligence.
  DATA(lo_extract) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Extract key purchasing patterns from: {T}'
    iv_sys = 'Return as structured JSON with trends'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).

  DATA(lo_opportunities) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Based on patterns {T}, identify 3 upsell opportunities'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).

  DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
    ( lo_extract ) ( lo_opportunities )
  ) ).

  DATA(ls_customer) = get_customer_patterns( iv_customer ).
  RETURN lo_flow->exec( REF #( ls_customer ) ).
ENDMETHOD.

Result: SAP data ‚Üí AI analysis ‚Üí Business recommendations in 30 seconds.

Load Balancing: Right Model, Right Cost

" Smart routing based on complexity
DATA(lo_llm_smart) = zcl_llm_00_llm_lazy_composite=>new(
  io_llm       = lo_llm_mini     " Fast, cheap model
  io_llm_exp   = lo_llm_maxi     " Powerful, expensive model 
  iv_threshold = 1000            " Token threshold
).

" Simple queries ‚Üí Mini model (fast + cheap)
" Complex queries ‚Üí Maxi model (powerful + expensive)

 

 

PREDICTOKEN: The Secret Weapon

" Predict tokens before expensive API calls
DATA(lv_predicted_tokens) = zcl_llm_00_predictoken=>predict_tokens_gpt4( lv_text ).

IF lv_predicted_tokens < 500.
  lo_llm = lo_llm_mini.     " Cheap model
ELSEIF lv_predicted_tokens > 8000.
  lo_flow = lo_split_flow.  " Split into multiple calls
ENDIF.

Accuracy: 99.7% token prediction (R¬≤ > 0.997 on 50,000+ validation samples) without API calls.

One-Click Invoice Intelligence

Complete invoice processing workflow:

DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_extract_invoice_data )     
  ( lo_validate_against_po )      
  ( lo_flag_anomalies )          
  ( lo_generate_approval_routing )
  ( lo_update_workflow_system )  
) ).

" Process 1000 invoices in parallel
DATA(lo_parallel) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy_parallel=>new(
  io_step = lo_flow->to_step( )
  io_llm  = lo_llm
).

Getting Started: The 10-Minute Setup

 

  1. Run: ZLLM_00_ONBOARD - Configure your LLM endpoints
  2. Demo: ZLLM_00_FLOW_DEMO - See chaining in action
  3. Build: Your first workflow in pure ABAP

 

DATA(lo_llm) = zcl_llm=>new( 'DEFAULT.ENV' ).
DATA(lo_step) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
  iv_usr = 'Analyze this data: {T}'
  io_llm = lo_llm
).
DATA(lr_result) = lo_step->exec( REF #( your_business_data ) ).

The "But What About..." Section

"What about Python's rich AI ecosystem?" Over half of enterprise AI work is data movement, not algorithms. ZLLM excels at the majority use case.

"What about scaling?" SAP systems already handle your enterprise load. ZLLM scales with your existing infrastructure.

"What about vendor lock-in?" ZLLM actually reduces vendor lock-in. You can hot-swap your LLM including self-hosted Ollama - try this with Joule üòÉ

# Monday: Local Ollama (zero vendor dependency)
API_MODEL=codellama
API_URL=http://localhost:11434/
API_KEY=ollama

# Tuesday: Switch to Azure (same ABAP code)
API_AZURE_FULL_URL=https://your-domain.openai.azure.com/...
API_KEY=your-azure-key

# Wednesday: Your own inference cluster
API_MODEL=your-custom-model
API_URL=http://your-internal-cluster/v1/
API_KEY=internal

One framework, any LLM provider. Change your .env file, restart your program. That's it.

Meanwhile, Joule ties you to whatever models SAP decides to support. ZLLM works with anything that speaks OpenAI API - including models that don't exist yet.

Why This Changes Everything

Before ZLLM: AI projects required new infrastructure, teams, security reviews, integration patterns, deployment processes.

After ZLLM: AI projects are ABAP development projects. Use existing everything.

The "cold start problem" disappears because there's no cold start. Your AI capabilities live where your business logic lives.

The Enterprise AI Future

This isn't another AI framework. This is enterprise AI that makes business sense:

 

  • ‚úÖNo integration projects - AI lives in your business logic
  • ‚úÖNo new infrastructure - Use your existing SAP systems
  • ‚úÖNo new security model - Inherit SAP's proven security
  • ‚úÖNo new deployment process - Deploy like any ABAP development

 

AGI* has been achieved. Now your ABAP can generate intelligence.

Ready to eliminate your AI integration hell?

‚≠êStar & Fork on GitHub - Get early access to the framework

Comment below: What's your most painful SAP business process? Let's see how ZLLM can eliminate that pain.

Build in hours what took quarters‚Äîor never shipped‚Äîsix months ago.

The ideal enterprise AI integration is one that doesn't exist because the capability is native: "we already have an LLM at home!"

About the Author:

Alice Vinogradova is a Senior Software Engineer with two decades of ABAP/SAP experience and a passion for practical AI integration. She specializes in eliminating complexity through innovation, bringing cutting-edge AI capabilities to conservative enterprise environments without the traditional integration overhead.

P.S. This framework exists because I got tired of explaining why enterprise AI projects fail. Better to build the solution than argue about the problem. ^_^

*ABAP Generative Intelligence üòÉ

**No external API, except LLM of course.

entry.title: New Custom Heuristic for Campaign Planning in PP/DS based on Order Quantity Thresholds
entry.content:
Summary

This blog post describes how to create a new custom heuristic for automatic creation of production campaigns from neighboring orders that have the same setup group, for specific customer business case where a minimum and a maximum number of units per campaign must be considered.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the heuristic algorithms for PP/DS.

 

Introduction

In Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS), production campaign planning allows businesses to group related production orders together for more efficient production scheduling and cost allocation. This is particularly useful in process industries where production lines may require setup or cleaning between processing different production batches or before downtimes. By grouping orders into campaigns, you can optimize the sequence of operations, reduce setup costs, and potentially lower storage costs. 

You mainly use production campaigns in companies that manufacture their products on production lines. Campaign planning functions can combine orders for similar or identical products into production campaigns. This consolidation help reduces setup and storage costs significantly, allowing products to be manufactured in a single manufacturing process over a longer period.

You can decide whether you want to use campaign optimization to plan campaigns or campaign heuristics. If you want to use campaign optimization for your planning, the following requirements must be met:

  • You use only one bottleneck resource within a production data structure model or, if there are more bottleneck resources, they are defined as alternative resources only.
  • There are no cross-order relationships or pegging relationships between the activities at the bottleneck resource.

If these requirements are not met, then you can use campaign heuristics to plan campaigns automatically.

 

Campaign Planning

Campaign planning can utilize either campaign optimization or campaign heuristics. You can plan campaigns in PP/DS as follows:

  • Automatically
    • By using campaign optimization, in which the system creates campaigns. The system tries to find an optimum number and sequence of orders in a campaign, as well as the sequence between the campaigns, while taking setup and storage costs into account.
    • By processing the campaign heuristics in sequence.
  • Manually. You can use the detailed scheduling planning board or campaign transaction to determine the number and sequence of orders in a campaign, as well as the sequence between the campaigns.

During scheduling, the system checks the following campaign-specific requirements for those resources you specified as campaign-relevant:

  • The activities of a campaign cannot be interrupted by activities that do not belong to orders of the same campaign.
  • You can position an order at the beginning or end of a campaign. Setup orders, for example, are always at the beginning of a campaign, and cleaning orders are always at the end.

The system schedules the orders at these resources so above requirements are not violated. Furthermore, the minimum resource commitment is also considered, which means that when scheduling campaigns and their orders, the system tries to occupy as few resources as possible. If you use alternative modes, all activities of a campaign must take place at the same resource.

The system only checks the above campaign requirements for the resources if the following indicators are set:

  • The ‚ÄúCampaign-Relevant‚Äù indicator in the resource master.
  • The ‚ÄúConsider Campaign Requirements‚Äù indicator in the strategy profile.

Figure 1: ‚ÄúCampaign-Relevant‚Äù indicator in the resource master.

Figure 2: ‚ÄúConsider Campaign Requirements‚Äù indicator in the strategy profile.

 

Main Tools and Features for Campaign Planning

The main tools and features to manage campaign planning are:

  1. Detailed Scheduling Planning Board: transaction /SAPAPO/CDPS0 provides a graphical view of campaigns and orders, allowing you to plan and schedule campaigns visually.
  2. Campaign transaction: transaction /SAPAPO/PCMT provides a table-based view of campaigns, orders, and dates, offering a more structured approach to campaign planning.
  3. Campaign heuristics: a feature that can be used to optimize the planning of campaigns by automatically generating a finite production plan.

By using these tools, the following campaign functions among others are available:

  • Create campaigns.
  • Dissolve campaigns.
  • Remove orders from campaign.
  • Add orders into existing campaign.
  • Splitting campaigns.
  • Merging campaigns.
  • Move orders from one campaign to another.
  • Create cleaning/setup orders.

Figure 3: Visual representation of a campaign in the detailed scheduling planning board.

Figure 4: Table-based view of a campaign in the campaign transaction.

Figure 5: Example of campaign heuristics functions in the detailed scheduling planning board.

Campaigns are visually represented by bars above the operation bars, covering the operations within the campaign. You can use drag and drop to move the campaign bars on the time axis. The planning functions of the detailed scheduling planning board help you to schedule campaigns. By default, the campaign bar label includes the campaign number, description, and status. You can also access the PP/DS campaign number when using the product view (transaction /SAPAPO/RRP3).

The campaign number comes from an internal number range defined on transaction PCMNO. When saving the campaign, an external campaign number is also assigned containing the S/4HANA campaign number, from a number range defined on transaction CPCN:

Figure 6: Example of internal and external campaign number in PP/DS campaign transaction.

Figure 7: Example of external campaign number in S/4HANA campaign transaction.

When manually creating a campaign, you can select its color from a designated palette of campaign colors (six colors available). When automatically planning campaigns, the system automatically assigns the color specified in the campaign profile. The campaign profiles can be managed either through transaction /SAPAPO/PCMP directly or through the following customizing path: IMG -> Advanced Planning -> Production Campaign Planning --> Maintain Campaign Profile.

Figure 8: Palette of available colors for campaigns visualization.

In the campaign profile, you perform settings which the system uses to create campaigns and for campaign optimization. You create a campaign profile for a certain location and setup group. The ‚ÄúMaximum Number of Charges in a Campaign‚Äù specifies the maximum number of orders possible per campaign when using the setup group entered. The ‚ÄúCampaign Color‚Äù specifies the display color of the bars that represent the production campaign in the resource chart of the detailed scheduling planning board. The default color for campaigns is violet, which is the one used by default if not campaign profile found by setup group.

Figure 9: Example of settings on the campaign profile.

This automatic coloring based on the campaign profiles will only work for automatic campaigns creation. If users are going to create campaigns manually, then they must enter the color manually or default color will be applied. This means that campaign profiles do not apply for manually created campaigns.

Every production campaign in PP/DS has a status that documents the campaign‚Äôs current processing status. The campaign status is derived from the status of the orders contained in the PP/DS campaign:

  • Status Created: The campaign either contains no orders or only orders that have neither been released nor started.
  • Status Released: The campaign contains at least one order that has been released and no order that has been started.
  • Status Started: The campaign contains at least one order that has been started.

The campaign status is also displayed graphically at the campaign bar in the detailed scheduling planning board. The status is indicated by various hatch patterns in the campaign bar.

  • Status Created: Colored, no hatch.
  • Status Released: Colored, diagonal stripe.
  • Status Started: Colored, diagonal crosshatch.

  

Figure 10: Example of campaign bar display on the base of the production campaign status.

 

Standard Heuristics for Production Campaigns

A heuristic is a planning function that executes planning for selected objects using a particular algorithm. In this way, the focus of planning can be products, orders, operations, resources, or line networks. Several standard heuristics are available for campaign planning. You can use them in the production planning run or interactively in the detailed scheduling planning board to process production campaigns. The available heuristics for campaign planning are the following:

  1. Create production campaigns (algorithm SAP_PCM_CRT, function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_CREATE)

Using this heuristic, you create production campaigns from neighboring orders that manufacture the same product or have the same setup group, depending on the heuristic setting.

  1. Dissolve production campaigns (algorithm SAP_PCM_DIS, function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_DISSOLVE)

Using this heuristic, you delete production campaigns, for example, before you let PP/DS optimization process your plan. The algorithm deletes as many orders as possible from all campaigns with the selected properties, and then deletes the campaigns that do not contain any orders.

  1. Delete setup/clean-out orders (algorithm SAP_PCM_ODEL, function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_ORDERS_DELETE)

Using this heuristic, you delete production setup/clean-out orders, for example, before you let PP/DS optimization process your plan. The sequence-dependent setup activity at the beginning of the campaign that had duration 0 as the successor of the setup/clean-out order increases by the value defined in the setup matrix for the new sequence.

  1. Adjust setup/clean-out orders (algorithm SAP_PCM_SRVA, function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_SERVICE_ADAPT)

Using this heuristic, you create setup/clean-out orders for a campaign. The algorithm deletes all existing setup/clean-out orders and then replaces all existing sequence-dependent setup activities at the beginning of a campaign with a setup/clean-out order.

To use campaign heuristics in the detailed scheduling planning board, you must define a heuristic profile that contains the corresponding campaign heuristics and assign it to the overall profile of the detailed scheduling planning board. This is done through the following customizing path: IMG -> Advanced Planning -> Heuristics -> Maintain Heuristic Profiles.

Figure 11: Example of heuristic profile containing several campaign heuristics.

To call up a heuristic in the detailed scheduling planning board, you select the relevant objects and choose menu option ‚ÄúFunctions‚Äù > ‚ÄúHeuristics‚Äù. To use the heuristic in the production planning run, you specify the processing steps you want to carry out and select the relevant objects. All the campaign heuristic algorithms consider the settings made in the campaign profile and in the definition of the heuristic.

When you define a heuristic, you first select the algorithm for the heuristic and second define the settings for the heuristic. This is done either through transaction /SAPAPO/CDPSC11 directly or through the following customizing path: IMG -> Advanced Planning -> Heuristics -> Maintain Heuristics.

Figure 12: Example of default heuristic settings for heuristic ‚ÄúCreate production campaigns‚Äù.

To change the default settings relevant to the heuristic, you choose Settings for Heuristic in the detailed scheduling planning board.

Figure 13: Example of heuristic settings maintained on detailed scheduling planning board.

The list with the detailed steps of the overall campaign planning flow with campaign heuristics would the following:

 

Step

Description

1

Planning orders are created by MRP Live.

2

You delete existing campaigns, setup and clean-out orders using the heuristics ‚ÄúDissolve campaign‚Äù and ‚ÄúDelete setup/clean-out orders‚Äù since PP/DS optimization cannot process them.

3

You start PP/DS optimization for selected resources (bottleneck resources) in the detailed scheduling planning board or the production planning run.

4

PP/DS optimization creates an order sequence with optimized setup times at the selected resources. Storage costs cannot be considered.

5

Using the heuristic ‚ÄúCreate production campaigns‚Äù, you let the system create campaigns consisting of orders that follow each other and have the same setup group or product in the detailed scheduling planning board or the production planning run.

6

If you want to use setup or clean-out orders, you execute the heuristic ‚ÄúAdjust setup/clean-out orders‚Äù or the function ‚ÄúAdjust setup/clean-out orders‚Äù in the detailed scheduling planning board. The system replaces sequence-dependent setup activities by setup or clean-out orders.

7

If required, you correct the planning in the detailed scheduling planning board or the campaign transaction and eliminate campaign alerts . You can assign additional orders to campaign.

8

You fix campaigns if you do not want them to be changed by another automatic planning run. You freeze the scheduling result.

9

If the planning situation changes, you start again with step 2.

10

You convert the planning to process orders for SAP S/4HANA.

 

New custom heuristic for creation of production campaigns based on quantity thresholds

The standard algorithm SAP_PCM_CRT for creation of production campaigns (function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_CREATE) creates new production campaigns and assigns orders to them. The algorithm assumes that you use finite scheduling and the procedure for activity/order assignation and sequencing is the following:

  1. The algorithm chronologically sorts all activities on the selected campaign-relevant resources in the planning period, defined by the selected time profile.
  2. The algorithm creates production campaigns from all neighboring activities with the following requirements:
    • The activities are not already part of a production campaign.
    • The activities are not fixed.
    • The activities are not deallocated.
    • The activities have the same setup group or produce the same product, depending on the settings for the heuristic.

The algorithm also takes the settings defined in the campaign profile into consideration. For instance, if for certain location and setup group a campaign profile exists, only the defined maximum number of orders possible per campaign are allowed. You can also use the campaign requirement indicator in the settings for the heuristic to determine if campaigns can be interrupted by downtimes, for example.

Customer business case was that they did not want to restrict a maximum number of orders possible per campaign, but they needed to define a minimum and a maximum number of units per campaign. This units will be in the production unit of measure of the orders. The required criteria for campaign aggrupation were the same setup group.

SAP provides a lot of standard heuristics for planning in PP/DS, but also have an option to create your own custom heuristics either through transaction /SAPAPO/CDPSC11 directly or else through the following customizing path IMG -> Advanced Planning -> Heuristics -> Maintain Heuristics.

When creating the new custom heuristic, first step is to select the algorithm for the heuristic. The way to proceed is to copy the standard function module /SAPAPO/HEUR_PCM_CREATE into a custom function module containing the own logic and copy other auxiliar function modules in case custom changes are also required.

Second step is to define the settings for the heuristic. In our business case, the two parameters containing the ‚ÄúMinimum Campaign Units‚Äù and the ‚ÄúMaximum Campaign Units‚Äù were added. Furthermore, the corresponding ‚ÄúUnit of measure‚Äù for these two parameters was also added, to avoid issues with production units different than base units of measure, and to be valid for other scenarios.

Figure 14: Example of default heuristic settings for custom heuristic algorithm.

Figure 15: Example of custom heuristic settings maintained on detailed scheduling planning board.

As customer did not want to restrict a maximum number of orders possible per campaign, this parameter was leave it on 0 (no restrictions) on the customizing campaign profiles. The required changes were implemented on business logic on the new custom heuristic to consider minimum and maximum number of units per campaign.

If you would like to work with your own heuristics in the detailed scheduling planning board, two pre-requisites must be fulfilled to allow custom heuristics for execution:

  • The new custom heuristic must be contained on the heuristic profile assigned to the overall profile of the detailed scheduling planning board. Then, the new heuristic will appear in the list of available heuristics in the menu of interactive planning.
  • The new custom heuristic must also be maintained on the scope profile assigned to the material on the ‚ÄúAdvanced Planning‚Äù material master view, when the ‚ÄúScope Limitation‚Äù is selected as ‚ÄòPP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only‚Äô or ‚ÄòPP/DS Restricted‚Äô.

The heuristics algorithms other than from the above lists are not allowed.

Figure 16: Example of scope profile on ‚ÄúAdvanced Planning‚Äù material master view.

Figure 17: Example of custom heuristic algorithm allowed on scope profile.

The standard campaign text is the description of the leading material or a fixed text in case of empty description. Customer requested the main key of the resource code (work center code) to be placed on the campaign text. This was directly coded on the new custom logic by overwriting the standard code, but it is also possible to achieve by using BADI ‚Äú/SAPAPO/PCM01_TXTOPT‚Äù.

Figure 18: Example of production campaign text containing the resource key.

The planning log in PP/DS contains messages that the system issues during interactive planning or in background planning. You can use the planning log to analyze planning problems and identify the causes of the problems. On the ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù for the ‚ÄúPlanning Log‚Äù on the detailed scheduling planning board you can select which types of messages you want to display on the planning log, such as termination messages or warnings or all messages.

Figure 19: Example of settings for the planning log on the detailed scheduling planning board.

Review and analysis of heuristics logs is an important activity which helps planners rectify many errors and make sure that planning results are very accurate. Customer requested a more detailed planning log containing more messages relative to specific custom logic. This was directly coded on the new custom logic by adding the specific new control messages.

Figure 20: Example of custom messages displayed in the planning log on the detailed scheduling planning board.

 

When you run PP/DS heuristic in background, you can invoke transaction /SAPAPO/RRPLOG1 to display the planning log. For interactive planning, until you save, you cannot watch the log on transaction /SAPAPO/RRPLOG1.

Figure 21: Selection screen of transaction /SAPAPO/RRPLOG1 for displaying planning logs.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics for Finance: Apps, Architecture, and Implementation Tips
entry.content:
Introduction

If you come from the world of SAP R/3 or SAP ECC, you may hear the term ‚Äòembedded analytics‚Äô and assume it refers to a module or add-on, but it‚Äôs really a capability built into S/4HANA itself.

In this post, I‚Äôll walk through embedded analytics, showing some examples for finance and sharing a few thoughts based on my own experience.

The old paradigm

SAP R/3 and SAP ECC are transactional systems. They sit on top of traditional relational databases that are not optimised for analytical operations. They couldn‚Äôt efficiently calculate totals on the fly, never mind aggregation, filtering, sorting etc.

(That‚Äôs why the general ledger had totals tables like GLT0 and FAGLFLEXT).

Secondly, the SAP graphical user interface (SAP GUI), was relatively static. It wasn‚Äôt easy to create role or context specific transactions.

The new paradigm

From SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA, one of the biggest changes is the HANA database. It brings three new capabilities:

  1. In memory computing

  2. Columnar store

  3. Parallel processing.

Combined, these enable S/4HANA to efficiently handle analytical operations.

Secondly, the new user interface: Fiori, is built on common technologies, HTML, CSS, JavaScript etc. This makes Fiori less proprietary and more dynamic.

SAP positions Fiori as a design language as well as a set of apps. They have published a design system to allow customers to build their own apps. Many of the analytical apps we will look at are based on re-usable design templates.

Enter the ‚Äòanalytical app‚Äô

This combination of flexibility from Fiori and power from HANA means we can create role based analytical apps.

  • There is no longer a need to load data to a data warehouse
  • There is no longer a need to implement a separate analytics or dashboard user interface.

Fiori itself includes many transactional and analytical apps. With embedded analytics, we are referring to a subset of popular analytical apps.

I would break down embedded analytics into three categories:

  • Analytical apps
    • Overview pages
    • Analytical list pages
    • Multi-dimensional reports
    • Smart business KPIs
    • Review booklets
  • Tools
    • Query browser
    • View browser
  • Embedded SAP analytics cloud.

Let‚Äôs look at each one and discuss some examples.

Analytical Apps by Category

Before we start, let‚Äôs look at how to find information about apps online.

How to find apps

The Fiori app library is published online: Fiori apps library.

An important note is that app availability varies by S/4HANA version. For example, some apps will release in Cloud version first before coming to on-premise versions. Other apps may only be available in Cloud versions. For the purposes of this post, we will look at all versions. Some apps listed may only be available on the Cloud.

  1. Under categories, select ‚Äòall apps‚Äô (16,932 apps listed!)
  2. On the bottom right of the left sidebar, click the ‚Äòfilter‚Äô icon
  3. Enter some filters e.g. ‚ÄòAnalytical‚Äô apps, ‚ÄòFinance‚Äô line of business

This gives a much more focused list of apps to scroll through (351).

We will look at ‚Äòoverview‚Äô apps first. Enter ‚Äòoverview‚Äô in search to narrow the list further. A list of apps that include the following is shown:

  • Revenue accounting overview
  • General ledger overview
  • Accounts receivable overview
  • Sales accounting overview
  • Asset accounting overview
  • Accounts payable overview

 

Overview pages

Purpose

I would describe the overview page apps as analytical ‚Äòhome pages‚Äô for a function. They show more detail than a simple KPI, but less detail than a more focused report.

They could be considered an entry level view into the analytics for the area in question.

Overview pages have a consistent layout. A header at the top with a range of search fields, followed by the content area, which is made up of cards. The cards may have charts, values, links etc. Users can drill down from the cards to see more detail.

Content ‚Äòcards‚Äô are a well-established concept in frontend design, and it‚Äôs good to see SAP embrace this.

SAP provide several standard overview pages. Customers can develop their own.

Example ‚Äì General ledger overview

I found two different iterations of the general ledger overview. The first is from the Fiori app library, the second from the analytics SAP help page. This highlights how pages can be set up differently.

Layout and contents

They are split into two main content sections:

Filter toolbar at the top:

  • The filter affects all the cards on the page
  • Adapt filter can be used to add/remove fields
  • A set of filters can be saved as a variant. For example ‚Äì a range of company codes.

Multiple cards are displayed below the filters:

  • The cards show either charts or lists
  • Users can move or hide cards. A card can be set as mandatory
  • Examples of cards for general ledger overview include:
    • G/L account balance
    • Recognised revenue
  • Drill-down is possible at multiple levels:
    • Click the card header for less granular drill down
    • Click card detail such as a bar chart column to see details

My thoughts

I like these overview pages. They come across as a classic functional dashboard. Having this directly in S/4HANA is great.

Key here is the customisation. If we take a typical general ledger accountant or manager, their focus tends to vary widely by organisation and industry.

In financial services, for example, I would want my overview screen to show recent transactions on certain accounts where accuracy and substantiation of assets is critical.

In manufacturing, I may want a view more oriented towards cost of goods sold or profit and loss by function.

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever encountered a G/L accountant who cared about days payables outstanding, so it‚Äôs unusual to see that there. I could understand a cash flow metric being there, though.

References

  • Fiori app library ‚Äì general ledger overview
  • SAP help ‚Äì general ledger overview
  • Best practices ‚Äì SAP Fiori Analytical Apps for G/L Accounting
  • Help SAP ‚Äì SAP UI5 development ‚Äì overview pages

Analytical list pages (ALP)

Purpose

Analytical list pages aim to bring together analytical and transactional work. The idea is to combine an analytical view with transaction data such that, the analytics provide a basis to act.

The best examples of these layouts combine a filter, a chart and a work list of items into one page.

In the Fiori app library, these will be marked as Fiori elements apps. SAP provide templates, customer can also create their own. They all have headers which allow for filtering and sorting.

Example: Commitments by cost centre

Commitments is a great example. An accountant may want to monitor commitments to spot something that is out of line with plan or previous period actuals.

In case you are not familiar with commitments, let‚Äôs go into more detail.

In this app you can compare commitments, actuals, and plan/budget:

  • Commitments: these are goods or services you have agreed to buy but haven‚Äôt yet received or paid for. There is no accounting impact yet: consider them as planned future expenses
    • In S/4HANA this could be a purchase requisition or purchase order with no goods receipt or invoice receipt
    • Commitments data comes from the extension ledger in the universal journal
  • Actuals: actual accounting postings to cost centres come from the universal journal (ACDOCA) main ledger
  • Budget/plan: can either come from the universal journal plan table (ACDOCP) or BW.

S/4HANA utilises ‚Äòextension ledgers‚Äô for commitment tracking, an example:

  • Purchase requisition/purchase order (PR/PO) for ¬£10,000
    • Commitment created for ¬£10,000 (if the PO is linked to a cost centre)
  • Goods receipt (GR) is received
    • Commitment is reduced by ¬£10,000
    • Actual cost is posted for ¬£10,000 (via accounting journal)
  • Invoice receipt (IR) is received
    • Clears GR/IR account and finalises the transaction

In ECC commitment information was stored in CO tables. With the S/4HANA changes it has moved to an extension ledger of the universal journal. It is separated out from the main ledger (ACDOCA) as these aren‚Äôt accounting postings.

This app pulls:

  • Actuals from ledger 0L
  • Commitments from extension ledger (usually OE)

Example 2: Allowance for doubtful accounts

Shifting from payables to receivables, another good example is doubtful debts. This app is called allowance for doubtful accounts.

The chart on the top half does an excellent job of showing the difference between overdue receivables and allowances made.

This may trigger an accountant to either change the allowances made or to follow up on some overdue items.

The customer balances are shown under the chart, and the accountant can drill down into the individual line items.

Layout and contents

  • Header to set filters
    • Compact display: simple drop-down lists (see example 1)
    • Visual display: mini charts (see example 2)
  • Content area 1: charts/lists
    • Charts are shown summarising KPIs to identify areas to investigate
    • There is a toolbar to change chart/list types and content
    • Charts are interactive. Clicking on them filters the work list shown below
  • Content area 2: list of transactions i.e. work list
    • Add/remove fields
    • You can 'group' transactions by dimension in settings
    • Drill-down using a variety of apps to different levels of detail

References

  • App library ‚Äì commitments by cost center
  • Help sap ‚Äì commitments by cost center
  • App library ‚Äì allowance for doubtful accounts
  • Help sap ‚Äì allowance for doubtful accounts
  • Help ‚Äì SAP UI5 development ‚Äì analytical list page

Multidimensional reports

Purpose

These apps are analytical queries. You could think of them like pivot tables in MS Excel. They allow you to select different dimensions and choose whether to split data into rows or columns via those dimensions.

They are a special kind of Fiori app labelled as Web Dynpro apps in the app library.

Like other apps, they‚Äôre launched from tiles on the Fiori launchpad. However, they can also be launched from the query browser, which will be discussed later.

Multidimensional report capabilities:

  • Usually a long list of dimensions (depends on the query)
  • Sorting
  • Filtering
  • Switching dimensions
  • Pivot
  • Add totals
  • Display data hierarchically
  • Drill-down
  • Bookmark navigation state - makes it easy to share or return after drill-down
  • Save page layout (after organising)
  • Export to MS Excel or PDF
  • Create new Fiori tile from the report
  • Navigate to other apps
    • For example, from a customer you can use the right click context menu to navigate to apps such as view sales order, change sales order

As these multidimensional reports are based on queries that contain many fields, users need to select what‚Äôs of interest to them via the navigation panel.

Example: Balance sheet/income statement ‚Äì multidimensional

  • Generated ‚Äòon the fly‚Äô from line items (ACDOCA)
  • Can select operational, local or group chart of accounts
  • Drill down into individual G/L account line items
  • Export to excel or PDF
  • Various features
    • Add dimensions such as profit centre, segment
    • Show various currencies
    • Compare periods
    • Compare actual / plan
    • Compare actuals across multiple ledgers
    • Link through to ‚Äòdisplay G/L account balances‚Äô, ‚Äòdisplay line items in general ledger‚Äô etc.

This app is based on the CDS view C_FinStmntComparison. More on this later.

Example 2: Journal Entry Analyser

  • Overview of aggregated amounts of selected journal entries by G/L account
  • You can choose to group by many options; company code, fiscal year, posting date, business area, functional area, profit centre
  • Drill down into each journal to see detail

This app is based on the CDS view C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001. More on this later.

Layout and contents

  • Search filters at the top
  • Left side navigation panel, which allows you to select row and column fields
  • Data table to the bottom/right

References

  • Fiori app library ‚Äì balance sheet/income statement - multidimensional
  • SAP help ‚Äì balance sheet/income statement - multidimensional
  • Fiori app library ‚Äì journal entry analyser
  • SAP help ‚Äì journal entry analyser
  • Multidimensional data grid apps
  • Data analyser reports

Smart business key performance indicators (KPIs)

Purpose

These are tiles that you place on the Fiori launchpad to show specific key performance indicators (KPIs). The KPIs can be shown as values or via mini charts.

SAP delivers various predefined KPIs. Users can select them from a role-based catalogue.

Custom KPIs can also be created.

The KPI tiles support drill down into more detail via other analytical apps. For example, drill down into a multidimensional report. See also the section on analytical path framework at the end.

Example: Accounts payable

This screenshot from SAP learning shows various KPI tiles for Accounts Payable arranged on a Fiori launchpad page. The first is ‚Äòoverdue payables‚Äô ‚Äì app ID F1746 (SAP Help / Fiori app library).

Layout and contents

  • Individual tiles organised on Fiori Launchpad pages
  • Tiles show either values or mini charts
  • Tiles can be configured to highlight value based on predefined ranges. In the example cash discount utilisation is highlighted in red.

My thoughts

These tiles are very useful. It‚Äôs a flexible way to build a dashboard for a specific user role. The embedded analytics features: real-time data, and drill-down add a lot of power here.

To get the most out of this requires some thought. A common mistake a project team might make is to throw all Accounts Payable KPIs on a single page for an AP clerk or AP manager. However, if you think about these KPIs, the context of how the information can be used varies widely.

I could envision a set of KPIs for an Accounts Payable clerk or manager that they may review and action daily. This could include overdue payables. Personally, I may want to add KPI tiles for topics such as blocked invoices, or payment status for critical vendors.

On the other hand, I may set up a different page for the monthly reviews that include KPIs like invoice processing time, ageing analysis, reversals etc.

References

  • SAP Help ‚Äì manage KPIs and reports
  • SAP Help ‚Äì financial statement based KPIs

Review booklets

Purpose

Review booklets combine multiple related reports into a collection of easy to navigate pages.

One of the first review booklets was "group financial statements". This makes sense, as the financial statements are a set of reports that together measure the state of an organisation.

Features of review booklets:

  • Utilise analytical queries
  • Similar functionalities to multidimensional reports; pivot tables, drill-downs, hierarchies
  • As with other apps, this is a template design. Review booklets can be created or adapted
  • Group Financial Statements includes:
    • Consolidated balance sheet
    • Profit and loss statement
    • Cash flow statement
    • Statement of changes in equity

Review booklets are a good example of apps that were delivered in S4/HANA cloud first. I believe the first booklets will be available for on-premise this year.

Example: Group financial statements (F6133)

Other examples

  • Cost centers review booklet (F7763)
  • Group view on accounting (F6401)
  • Service and profitability review booklet (F6600)

Layout and contents

  • Global filters: affect content on all pages
  • Page filters: affect the content on a single page
  • The booklet is split into page groups (like tabs)
  • Each page group has one or more pages to subdivide the topic
  • Each page shows pivots and/or charts side by side
  • Columns and rows can be adjusted
  • Side toolbar: from multidimensional reports
  • Right sidebar: with formatting options
  • Navigate from review booklets to other apps
    • Global and page filters are applied as you navigate.

Views can be saved and shared if authorisation allows.

References

  • Fiori app library ‚Äì group financial statement review booklet
  • SAP help ‚Äì group financial statements review booklet
  • Review booklets
  • Review booklet designer

Query browser

Purpose

The query browser isn‚Äôt an analytical app itself; it‚Äôs an app to search for analytical queries. You can however launch analytical queries from within the query browser. This opens them as multidimensional reports.

Analytical queries are a special type of CDS view. I will cover this later under solution architecture. I‚Äôll note here that you can browse finance CDS view online. Help portal ‚Äì CDS views for Finance.

If you click on CDS views for general ledger and then look for items with a technical name starting C_\ these are analytical queries. For example, in this list, we can see the query C_FinStmntComparison that was used in the balance sheet/income statement multidimensional report.

Query features

  • SAP provides many standard queries
  • Customers can develop their own queries
  • Access to queries is role-based
  • Queries can be added to favourites
  • Queries collect data by business scenario
  • The data is projected into the multidimensional analysis tool

Note that the query browser does not identify underlying views or source tables, but the view browser can show this.

Example

Unfortunately, I don‚Äôt have a screenshot of a finance query to hand, but here is a screenshot of the sales order item query (C_SalesOrderItemQry):

Note the "open for analysis" button on the bottom right, this will open the query as a multidimensional report.

Layout and contents

On the first page, you will see a list of analytical queries. For navigation:

  • Search: search for analytical views (or tables, view descriptions, column names, annotations, user tags)
  • Filter: filter by tag or application component

After selecting a query, you will see query details and the option to open for analysis.

References

  • Fiori app library ‚Äì query browser
  • SAP help ‚Äì query browser

View browser

The query browser only shows analytical queries. Those are CDS views of type "consumption". However, the information presented is limited.

The view browser shows all CDS views with more detail.

Analytics ‚Äì view browser

Embedded SAC

Purpose

So, SAP analytics cloud is a whole other thing!

But you get a taste of analytics cloud with embedded analytics called ‚ÄòSAP analytics cloud embedded version‚Äô

To illustrate the difference, we could consider `stories`: one of the key features of analytics cloud. This is where we bring together values, charts, and other visualisations: images, pictograms, etc. to create a story.

For example, a management accountant may use multidimensional reports for analysis. They may then use a story to link together various pieces of information to explain a situation. A simple example might be showing a decline in profitability in a story which highlights a couple of connected things, reducing volume from a key customer and increasing costs for a particular cost centre.

What exactly is included with the 'SAP analytics cloud embedded version'?

  • Limited set of features
  • S/4HANA data only
  • Wrapped in Fiori UI
  • Stories can be set as jump targets from embedded analytics apps
  • Small number of predefined stories
  • Ability to create your own stories

Example: operating income

Source: SAP learning

Example: working capital

Source: SAP help

References

  • SAP help ‚Äì stories
  • SAP help ‚Äì integrate SAP analytics cloud content
  • SAP help ‚Äì data visualisations (stories)

Other items

Analytical path framework

When browsing analytical apps, you may come across this term.

This is the approach to define how you drill down from KPIs into details. For example, from a KPI you may want to drill down into a chart, then from the chart into multidimensional reporting.

Analysis path framework

Solution Architecture

Let‚Äôs look at the main components of the solution architecture.

Embedded analytics is made possible by:

  1. The performance capabilities of HANA database tables
  2. Various features of Fiori (web-based, flexible, role-based, extensible etc.)

One piece of the puzzle which I‚Äôve hinted at but not explained is the virtual data model, which sits between the tables and Fiori.

Virtual data model (VDM)

SAP database tables are mostly structured by module and business transaction. Analytical apps in Fiori are structured by user-role and business scenario. We need a way to bridge this gap.

In a simple application, data is retrieved from tables directly using code (usually SQL).

However, as we are talking about thousands of tables and thousands of apps, SAP came up with a better way to manage this.

This is the virtual data model (VDM).

As per the name, it‚Äôs a virtual structure only. Data is not stored in the VDM.

The VDM is made up of core data services views (CDS views), it will make more sense if we describe those.

Core data services (CDS)

Think of a CDS view as the specification of a set of fields along with information about those fields. They are code based and are a mix of SQL and SAP proprietary language.

CDS views are structured into layers:

  • Basic views
    • These are the lowest level CDS views
    • They get data from tables
    • In finance think ACDOCA, SKB1 etc.
  • Composite views
    • These can‚Äôt read tables, but can read other views
    • These can‚Äôt be consumed by apps
    • In finance, for example, this could be now a combination of tables
  • Consumption views
    • Think of these as the queries
    • They are ready to be consumed by apps
    • These views are based on what the analytical app needs.

An example ‚Äì commitments.

Earlier in this post, we discussed an analytical app based on commitment data. That app required commitments, actuals and plan/budgets. That means the consumption view would be an aggregation of all of this data. This consumption view will rely on many composite views, which in turn rely on several basic views.

In addition to many standard CDS views, customers can create their own.

Available CDS views can be seen on SAP help.

Fiori

Fiori is positioned as a design system as well as a set of apps.

Many of these apps are based on design templates that can be used to create your own apps. Fiori itself is a large topic; in this post I‚Äôd just highlight a few key points:

  • The Fiori frontend is based on standard technologies; HTML, CSS, JavaScript bundled together into SAP‚Äôs framework SAPUI5 (SAP developed JS framework based on OpenUI5)
  • Fiori connects to the S/4HANA backend using OData services (ABAP RESTful protocol). This connects Fiori to the CDS views
  • Fiori apps are typically launched from the Fiori Launchpad (FLP), which runs in a browser and handles navigation, user roles, app tiles, etc.

So, when you use one of these Fiori apps generally what is happening is:

  1. Fiori app (JS) ‚Üí calls OData endpoint (/sap/opu/odata/....)
  2. OData service ‚Üí implemented via an ABAP backend (often based on CDS views)
  3. CDS view ‚Üí reads from HANA and pushes data back via the service

As a side note, in ECC, the SAP GUI client communicates with the ABAP server using proprietary protocols, which was much more difficult to customise.

Implementation considerations

Let‚Äôs consider two main scenarios:

  1. New S/4HANA implementations and upgrades from ECC
  2. S/4HANA already implemented, but with minimal Fiori and/or analytics.

For new implementations and upgrades, when we consider the core S/4HANA work, the workload is huge. The change management impact is huge. This is before thinking about Fiori or analytics.

It's challenging to get requirements and design right for the Finance (FI CO). This is especially true for large international organisations. Designing optimal chart of accounts, cost centre and profit centre hierarchies is a big exercise. On top of the basics, more complexity is introduced with topics like multiple ledgers, product cost control, and margin analysis.

Figuring out how to fit in analysis and design for Fiori and embedded analytics is tough.

Many projects will create an analytics work stream. In my view, this doesn't work well. Team members working on analytics need to understand the core model.

I can't emphasise enough how important it is to focus on core elements of FI/CO. Many organisations suffer for years due to poor design of profit centres, ledgers, business area etc.

The sheer number of Fiori apps is a challenge in itself. But as we've seen in this article, we can filter the list down to a more manageable focus area for finance.

When it comes to Fiori, on implementations, my suggestion is to start small. Target the Fiori apps that deliver the most value for an initial go-live, then follow up with a continuous improvement program to investigate more apps.

Core apps for go-live might look like:

  • The top few KPIs per function as Smart Business KPI tiles
  • Multi-dimensional reports for classic roles such as cost accountants, to replace any manual extraction and excel manipulation.

However, I recognise that some consultants may promote a 'Fiori first' approach: put Fiori at the centre of the project. This may be a better approach, but you must be careful not to lose focus on the core design.

In the case where S/4HANA is already implemented, an organisation is free to choose their own path depending on their current goals and available resources.

They could initiate a larger formal project to implement Fiori and/or embedded analytics. A business case could be constructed based on time saving and IT cost reduction (elimination of other apps).

On the other hand, this could be done through a longer running continuous improvement program driven by product managers or centres of excellence. I would generally lean towards the latter, as it poses less of a change impact on an organisation.

User-role mapping

Fiori is built around roles. It's good to see SAP moving towards a more nuanced understanding of business roles.

Smart business KPIs and overview pages align well to user roles, team roles, and function roles. However, one thing I'd like to highlight is how much these roles vary by:

  • Organisation type (public vs. private sector)
  • Organisation size (local vs. international organisations)
  • Industry (e.g. manufacturing vs. financial services)
  • Current challenges and opportunities (e.g. accounting issues, ongoing acquisitions etc.).

We need to be careful to ensure KPIs and overview page cards are relevant.

The best way to think about what‚Äôs relevant is to look at the organisation and function objectives. These translate into responsibilities and accountabilities for a team or user.

Responsibilities and accountabilities are executed by actions that are informed by the information.

To illustrate, my design thinking would work something like this:

Role: Accounts Payable clerk - Accountability: 98% payment on time

  • Payment on time KPI tile on launchpad, drill down to nearly due / overdue items
  • Blocked invoices tile on launchpad, drill down to line items

Role: Cost accountant ‚Äì Accountability: Monitor plan vs. actual on production costs

  • Tiles or overview pages focussed on certain cost elements, cost centres
  • Multidimensional reports to investigate further

When it comes to overview pages, I see potential for them to be designed for working groups, as well as individual roles.

For example, you may have an overview page oriented towards a monthly business review. This would cover all relevant aspects of revenue and cost.

Another overview page might relate to financial operations, which would cover operational metrics.

A further one could be related to financial stewardships and focus on metrics like manual journals or reversals, or transactions above a certain threshold.

These could be a useful tool for the facilitation of meetings and discussions. I think this is also true for review booklets.

Common pitfalls

Analytics for the sake of analytics.

The tiles look pretty. The charts look pretty. It‚Äôs tempting to just throw everything at a user.

I‚Äôd be very careful about this. Any content that we use should have a clear purpose. That purpose can either be an action or an escalation.

Reporting duplication.

Some of the reports in embedded analytics will duplicate or replace other analytical reporting. We should be careful to decide which report is the source of truth, any others should be retired.

I worked for a client once that had about 10 different versions of net profit, depending on which system you took the KPI from.

I've seen a significant number of issues arise during SAP implementations with the boundary between what I'd call 'trusted financial reporting' and broader analytics.

As soon as financial data leaves the finance function and gets into analytic systems, it can be so heavily manipulated it is no longer reconcilable to what's reported externally.

Examples of this include applying alternate hierarchies, running allocations etc. or even just simply filtering out data.

Analytic users may expect they can do similar things with embedded analytics. This is usually due to a lack of understanding of finance data.

There's no right or wrong answer here. I would say there are two truths:

  • There must be a clear source of 'accounting truth' for both external and internal management purposes. Everyone should understand what that is.
  • Further experimental manipulation should be possible somewhere, but it has to be understood that data is not trusted.

The role of embedded analytics vs. other tools should be clear.

Conclusions

Overall, embedded analytics are great. The team at SAP have done a great job in two areas:

Fiori:

  • Based on standard web technologies
  • Very well documented design system
  • Template approach with emphasis on a customer‚Äôs ability to create what they need

S/4HANA virtual data model

  • A smart way to define a huge range of data sets and make them available for consumption.

As someone who implemented R/3 and ECC several times, I wish we had embedded analytics and Fiori back then.

On the flip side, as with everything with SAP, it‚Äôs highly complex. This article just covered an overview, but each of these apps has a lot of detail to address:

  • Technical set up
  • Configuration
  • User settings
  • Options to create customer versions.

Some apps are only available in certain cloud versions, and some apps require certain configuration approaches in FI CO. There's a lot of hidden complexity behind this post.

For an organisation not using Fiori and embedded analytics, I‚Äôd suggest starting with those that deliver the most value, based on your current challenges and opportunities. The best way to do this is likely through setting up an expert role and potentially a continuous improvement program.

I‚Äôd like to cite and thank SAP for the good quality information that I gathered for this post:

  • Various pages on SAP Help: please see the links above throughout the document
  • SAP learning: Discovering Embedded Analytics
  • Fiori app library.
  • Analytics on the SAP Help Portal: 
    • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 
    • SAP S/4HANA

If you want to delve deeper I suggest working through the SAP learning course on Embedded Analytics as a starting point.

If you have any thoughts on this, please share in the comments.

I have a lot of other posts about finance transformation on my website or Linkedin. A few which may be of interest:

  • Centralised business services

  • SAP Finance: evolution of the data model

  • The chart of accounts: concept and design

  • SAP HANA and S/4HANA

  • Improving the Record to Report process

entry.title: You Won't Believe Where ZLLM's Documentation Lives (And How It Got There)

How I Made AI Write Its Own Documentation... In SAP's Standard Format

Spoiler: The AI is already documenting itself in production*.

Hello again! üëã It's Alice, and I have a confession: I absolutely love writing documentation.

But I hate writing it BY HAND. Especially in SAP's bizarre ITF format - that cryptic markup language designed back when the closest thing to modern markup was SGML, and HTML didn't even exist yet!

(Fun fact: ITF format was actually designed for SAPscript in the early 1980s as part of SAP R/2 - when "markup language" meant something completely different! ^_^)

But here's the thing - ZLLM has incredible documentation. Comprehensive, detailed, and perfectly formatted. And it lives exactly where every SAP developer NOT expects it: behind the standard "Show Documentation" button üòÉ

 

Plot Twist:

I didn't write a single line of that documentation manually.

ZLLM documented itself.

The Documentation That Writes Itself

Click on any ZLLM class in SE80 or ADT. Hit CTRL+SHIFT+F2 (Show Documentation).

What you'll see isn't your typical sparse ABAP documentation. It's rich, detailed, with examples, architecture diagrams, and usage patterns. All perfectly formatted in SAP's native documentation system.

Here's what makes this magical:

The documentation exists in standard SAP format (ITF), appears in standard SAP locations, but was generated by modern AI and written in human-readable Markdown first.

How I Built The Documentation Factory

Step 1: The Analysis Phase

" ZLLM analyzes the codebase
DATA(lo_analyzer) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
  iv_usr = 'Analyze this ABAP class and extract:'
           '- Purpose and responsibility'
           '- Public methods and parameters' 
           '- Usage patterns and examples'
           '- Integration points: {T}'
  io_llm = lo_llm
).

Step 2: The Generation Phase

" Generate comprehensive Markdown documentation
DATA(lo_generator) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
  iv_usr = 'Create technical documentation in Markdown format:'
           '- Overview section with clear purpose'
           '- Method documentation with examples'
           '- Code samples showing real usage'
           '- Integration notes and best practices'
           'Based on analysis: {T}'
  io_llm = lo_llm
).

Step 3: The Integration Magic

" Chain it all together
DATA(lo_doc_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_analyzer )
  ( lo_generator )
) ).

" Generate docs for entire framework
DATA(lr_result) = lo_doc_flow->exec( REF #( class_metadata ) ).

For the Markdown ‚Üí ITF conversion and integration with SAP's documentation system, I used another one of my frameworks: XRAY. But that's a story for another article... ^_^

The Real Magic: Production-Ready Documentation

This isn't a toy example. This is live, production documentation that:

‚úÖAppears in standard SAP tools (SE80, ADT, SE11)

‚úÖFollows SAP documentation conventions

‚úÖUpdates automaticallywhen code changes

‚úÖIncludes real examplesand usage patterns

‚úÖMaintains technical accuracy through AI analysis

Traditional SAP Documentation:

* It is a class.

ZLLM-Generated Documentation:

 

Why This Changes a Lot

For SAP Developers:

  • No more "TODO: Add documentation" comments
  • Comprehensive docs appear automatically in familiar places
  • Examples and usage patterns generated from actual code

For Enterprise Teams:

  • Documentation stays current with code changes
  • Consistent format across entire codebase
  • Onboarding new developers becomes trivial

For AI Adoption:

  • Demonstrates practical AI value in daily development
  • Shows integration with existing enterprise tools
  • Proves AI can enhance rather than replace existing workflows

The Recursive Beauty

Here's the beautiful irony: ZLLM used itself to document itself.

The framework that makes enterprise AI integration effortless also made documenting itself effortless. It's AI all the way down.

How You Can Build This

Want to auto-document your own ABAP code? Here's the starter pattern:

METHOD auto_document_class.
  " 1. Extract class metadata
  DATA(lo_metadata) = extract_class_info( iv_class_name ).
  
  " 2. Generate documentation
  DATA(lo_doc_step) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Create comprehensive documentation for this ABAP class: {T}'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).
  
  " 3. Chain and execute

    ( lo_doc_step )
  ) ).
  
  DATA(lv_markdown_doc) = lo_flow->start( REF #( lo_metadata ) )->to_string( ).
  
ENDMETHOD.

The Bigger Picture

This isn't just about documentation. It's about AI that enhances existing enterprise workflows instead of disrupting them.

Traditional AI Integration: "We need new tools, new processes, new training..."

ZLLM Approach: "Your existing tools just got smarter."

The documentation appears exactly where SAP developers (not?) expect it. No new interfaces to learn. No new processes to adopt. Just better, more comprehensive information in familiar places.

What's Next?

This is just one example of ZLLM eating its own dog food. Other production uses:

Code Analysis- Analyzing patterns across the entire ABAP stack

Performance Monitoring- Generating insights from system metrics

Test Generation- Creating unit tests from business requirements

It uses the ESG data that has already been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) and creates the reports based on the imported data. The AI generated reports are available to download in the .pdf format.

entry.title: Responding to AU CRFD with SAP Ariba and SAP Sustainability Solutions
entry.content:
Starting from the 1st of January 2025 as part of Australia‚Äôs Climate-related Financial Disclosure (CRFD) enactment, Australian companies will need to comply to a range of sustainability reporting requirements set out under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) and structured to Australian Accounting Standards Board (AASB) S2 Climate-related Disclosures, a standard aligning with the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) S2 framework.

One such reporting requirement is the disclosure of Scope 3 Category 1 Purchased Goods and Services (Scope 3.1) emissions. These are required in the second financial reporting year for each of the three entity groups impacted on a phased basis.

Companies already reporting to IFRS S2 will find it easier to comply to this new requirement. It was estimated that prior to the introduction of this climate-disclosure law, about 75% of ASX 200 companies have already reported in alignment with Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

Who is impacted?

Both listed and unlisted entities are required to report their Scope 3 emissions from their second reporting year onwards with the first group commencing this from the 1st of July 2025 as their second reporting year (the first proportioned FY commencing January 2025 to June 2025 since the disclosure came into effect on 1st January 2025).

From the 1st of July 2025, the following companies that meet the eligibility criteria below are required to disclose Scope 3 emissions for their second year of reporting:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

Or

National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Reporters (NGER)

 

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and subsidiaries under its control) totaling $500 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $1 billion or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 500 or more.

 

 

 

Companies that are registered under NGER to report and emit over 50 ktCO2 for the financial year for Scope 1 and 2 emissions under Section 13(1)(a).

 

And excludes Corporate Collective Investment Vehicles (CCIV), registrable superannuation entities or schemes.

From the 1st of July 2026, Group 2 entities will be required to disclose Scope 3 emissions in their second financial year (FY) of reporting:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

Or

National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Reporters (NGER)

Or

CCIVs, superannuation entities or registrable schemes.

 

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and subsidiaries under its control) totaling $200 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $500 million or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 250 or more.

 

 

 

All other companies that are registered under NGER Act to report.

 

 

End of financial year (EOFY) assets of $5 billion or more.

 

Followed lastly by Group 3 entities on the 1st of July 2027 with mandatory Scope 3 reporting in the second FY:

 

Meet at least two out of three criteria:

1.        Consolidated revenue of entities (and entities under its control) totaling $50 million or more.

2.        Consolidated total assets by the end of financial year totaling $25 million or more.

3.        Employee count by end of financial year totaling 100 or more.

 

Australian guidelines for Scope 3 reporting in procurement

Scope 3 emissions reporting follows AASB S2, which is aligned with ISSB IFRS S2 with some differences to what is needed for reporting. The reporting framework seeks to be compatible with EFRAG European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) guidelines. Within procurement, Scope 3.1 are the main emission data sources that purchasing needs to collect and report on.

What emissions calculation standard does AU CRFD follow?

All calculations for Scope 3 emissions follow the GHG Protocol as the international standard. The exchange of supplier-specific Scope 3 emissions data within the context of procurement can be done according to the World Business Council Sustainable Development (WBCSD) PACT V2/V3 standards. A newer version launched by WBCSD on April 2025 (PACT V3) seeks to make Scope 3 emissions disclosures easier and more accurate. Businesses would need to purchase Lifecycle Assessment (LCA) databases to gain access to missing emissions data so that they can be calculated as averages.

NGER calculations for entities covered under the Act are primarily concerned with Scope 1 and 2 emissions, and the Australian Government provides free guidelines for these as National Greenhouse Account Factors.

How can Australian companies be prepared for reporting procured emissions?

Knowing the difference between AASB S2 and IFRS S2 is key, where AASB S2 does not require industry specific disclosures. IFRS S2 guidelines provide industry-specific approaches towards reporting. However, it is currently being proposed that industry-specific methodologies be incorporated in reporting under AASB S2 and is scheduled to be completed by 2030.

The following steps can be taken by procurement to comply with AU CRFD:

  1. Start with your suppliers: Assess their maturity and begin requesting primary emissions data. There are tools that procurement solution providers offer to facilitate the exchange and calculation of Scope 3.1 emissions data between buyers and suppliers.
  2. Expand to include activities (both goods and contracted services) that you do not own: Identify activities that contain the highest carbon intensity and other carbon hotspots across the value chain.
  3. Encourage submission of actual emissions: While LCA calculations can help fill in missing averages, meaningful actions to decarbonize can only work with actual emissions data.
  4. Carbon calculators that use GHG Protocol methods: Don‚Äôt have actual Scope 3.1 emissions data? This is when an LCA carbon calculator comes in.
  5. Collect, manage and report on this data: Once purchased Scope 3.1 emissions are collected, they should be clearly segmented against the other 15 categories of Scope 3 emissions. Companies have different ways of storing this carbon data and exporting this for reporting purposes. Buyers should select a solution that provides a single source of carbon truth that is easily reportable.
  6. Work with the right contacts at your company: Align on your sustainability purchasing goals with compliance, finance, supply chain and sustainability leaders in your organization.
  7. Begin engaging with auditors: Prior to the CRFD review period lapsing, companies should begin engaging with auditors to ensure compliance and accuracy of collected information. Once these processes are established, reporting should become easier as companies expand their sustainable procurement maturity and compliance.
  8. Communicate sustainable procurement policies to stakeholders: Convey how sustainable purchasing policies are followed to address stakeholder expectations and when being assessed on environmental, social governance (ESG) risks by institutional graders. If there are gaps in Scope 3 emissions, explain why and how the company can get this data in the future.

Why should companies report now rather than wait?

There is growing international pressure on companies to disclose their sustainability finance and spend performance to key stakeholders, whether they are large institutional investors or smaller shareholders, ESG scores are one component of a company‚Äôs ability to attract better financial capital-raising opportunities. Therefore, sustainability transparency is a growing expectation by stakeholders on companies. It allows firms to be become better prepared when responding to changes in ESG reporting requirements, rather than delay and rush to implement a suitable solution. 

Our surveys show that business leaders are keeping sustainability in mind with a long-term goal. Despite sustainability delays, it is forecasted that disclosures will become more stringent with companies having added pressures to act on climate change, reduce their reliance on finite energy sources and volatile fossil fuel supply chains, improve circularity on critical resources, and stamp out human rights abuses. This important step starts from procurement, and it is one of the reasons why sustainable procurement is important due to the downward pressures exerted by the buyer.

Interested in sustainability reporting solutions with SAP Ariba and SAP Sustainability solutions?

At SAP, we have a range of sustainable procurement, carbon finance and enterprise resource planning (ERP) solutions to help advance your organization‚Äôs sustainability reporting goals ‚Äì providing an end-to-end reporting journey to help you comply to EFRAG ESRS, IFRS S/2 and AASB S2 sustainability reporting requirements. As well as helping customers comply to the Australian Modern Slavery Act of 2018 (Cth) through SAP Ariba supplier due diligence solutions.
