entry.title: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for India: Electronic Invoice in Utilities using Extensibility
entry.content:
You want to enable your system to create electronic documents for invoices posted in Utilities using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. In this blog, we‚Äôll show you an example on how this can be achieved using extensibilty.  

Prerequisite: 

Before you begin ensure that you have implemented the SAP Notes listed in 3569761 - Electronic Document Processing for India: Electronic Invoice using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition - Implementation Overview.‚ÄØYou can also refer the SAP Help Portal for more information, see Electronic Document Processing.‚ÄØ 

Steps to Create Electronic Documents

  • Append Structure Creation
    Create a 'Z' append structure to map utilities-specific fields to the source structure EDOC_IN_GEN_SOURCE. Include the following utilities-specific fields to the append structure.‚ÄØ
    Example: 

    Field Name 

    Component Type 

    Description 

    DOC_HEADER_ISU‚ÄØ 

    EDOC_ERDK‚ÄØ 

    eDocument: IS-U- Print Document/Header Data‚ÄØ 

    DOC_ITEM_ISU‚ÄØ 

    EDOC_ERDZ_TAB‚ÄØ 

    eDocument: IS-U Print Document - Item Data‚ÄØ 

    FKKVKP_ISU‚ÄØ 

    FKKVKP‚ÄØ 

    Contract Account Partner- Specific‚ÄØ 

    DFKKKO_ISU‚ÄØ 

    DFKKKO‚ÄØ 

    Header Data in Open Item Accounting Document‚ÄØ 

     
  • Implement FQEVENT R433 (Electronic Document Creation)
    Create a 'Z' function module to implement     FQEVENT R433, using the method PREPARE_EDOCUMENTS from the class CL_EDOC_SOURCE in FM. This method utilizes the factory class of eDocument IS-U to get an instance of the eDocument IS-U class. 
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION ZEDOC_ISU_IN_R433 .
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_BUPA) TYPE  EKUN_EXT
*"     REFERENCE(X_FKKVKP) TYPE  FKKVKP
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOC) TYPE  ISU21_PRINT_DOC
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOCNO) LIKE  ERDK-OPBEL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_UNIT) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT
*"     REFERENCE(X_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM
*"  TABLES
*"      T_VKK_DOC_ID TYPE  ISU21_T_VKK_DOC_ID
*"      T_BILL_DOC TYPE  ISU2A_T_BILL_DOC
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_land1       TYPE land1,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data,
        inv_doc        LIKE LINE OF t_vkk_doc_id,
        fkop           LIKE LINE OF inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_active,
         lv_msgtyp,
         lv_bukrs,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bapiret,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_t001,
         lt_edocument[],
         inv_doc,
         fkop.

  "Print Document Header
  ls_erdk = x_printdoc-erdk.

  READ TABLE t_vkk_doc_id INTO inv_doc WITH KEY id = 'A'.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    LOOP AT inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop INTO fkop
    WHERE NOT bukrs IS INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = fkop-bukrs.
      EXIT.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      SELECT SINGLE land1
        INTO lv_land1
        FROM t001
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0 AND lv_land1 EQ 'IN'.
        SELECT SINGLE active
          INTO lv_active
          FROM edocompanyactiv
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
            AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
        IF lv_active = 'X'.

          ls_fkkvkp = x_fkkvkp.

          TRY.
              ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
              MOVE-CORRESPONDING inv_doc-vkk_doc-fkkko TO ls_source_data-dfkkko.
              SELECT SINGLE *
                FROM t001
                INTO ls_t001
                WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
                ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
                ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
              ENDIF.
              ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
              ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
              ls_source_data-document_item = x_printdoc-t_erdz.
* Fill source document key
              cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                                                    IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

              GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
              lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

              IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

                lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                  iv_update_task = abap_true
                  iv_hook        = abap_true ).
                LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                  IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                    <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                  ENDIF.
                ENDLOOP.

              ENDIF.
            CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

              LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
                "Default type Error
                lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
                IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                  "eDocument has been created
                  IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                    lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                  ENDIF.
                ENDIF.
                MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                  WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                       ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
              ENDLOOP.

          ENDTRY.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Implement FQEVENT R428 (Reversal)
    Similarly, create a 'Z' function module to implement FQEVENT R428, using the same method as above for reversal process.
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION zedoc_isu_in_r428. "#EC CI_FUNCTION
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_DOC OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_CALL_ID) TYPE  C
*"  TABLES
*"      XYT_EITR TYPE  ISU21_T_EITR
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_invopbel    TYPE opbel_kk,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bukrs       TYPE eitr,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        ls_erdb        TYPE erdb,
        ls_dfkkko      TYPE dfkkko,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        lt_erdz        TYPE edoc_erdz_tab,
        lt_t001z       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t001z,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_bukrs,
         lv_active,
         lv_invopbel,
         lv_msgtyp,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bukrs,
         ls_t001,
         ls_erdb,
         ls_dfkkko,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_bapiret,
         lt_erdz[],
         lt_t001z[],
         lt_edocument[].

* This event should be trigger only for reversal process
  IF x_call_id = 'R'.

    LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-t_eitr INTO ls_bukrs
    WHERE bukrs IS NOT INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = ls_bukrs-bukrs.
    ENDLOOP.

    SELECT SINGLE *
      FROM t001
      INTO ls_t001
      WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
    IF ls_t001-land1 EQ 'IN'.

      SELECT SINGLE active
        INTO lv_active
        FROM edocompanyactiv
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
          AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      IF lv_active = 'X' AND
      x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk-opbel IS NOT INITIAL.

        ls_erdk = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk.
        lt_erdz = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-t_erdz.
        ls_fkkvkp =  x_reversal_doc-acc-fkkvkp.

        LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-old_print_doc-t_erdb INTO ls_erdb
        WHERE doc_id = 'A' OR doc_id = 'S'.
          lv_invopbel = ls_erdb-invopbel.
        ENDLOOP.

        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM dfkkko
          INTO ls_dfkkko
          WHERE opbel = lv_invopbel.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-dfkkko = ls_dfkkko.
        ENDIF.

        SELECT *
          FROM t001z
          INTO TABLE lt_t001z
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-t001z = lt_t001z.
        ENDIF.
        TRY.

* Source structure mapping
            ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
            ls_source_data-document_item = lt_erdz .
            ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
            ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
            ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
            ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
            ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
* fill source document key
            cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                      IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

            GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
            lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

            IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

              lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                                                                 iv_update_task = abap_true
                                                                 iv_hook = abap_true ).
              LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                  <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                ENDIF.
              ENDLOOP.

            ENDIF.
          CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

            LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
              "Default type Error
              lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
              IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                "eDocument has been created
                IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                  lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                ENDIF.
              ENDIF.
              MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                     ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
            ENDLOOP.

        ENDTRY.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Create Factory Class
    1. Create a 'Z' factory class to get the instance of eDocument IS-U class by inheriting CL_EDOC_FACTORY class and redefine its method CREATE_EDOC_INSTANCE. Example: ZCL_EDOC_FACTORY_IN_ISU
      Sample Code:  
  METHOD create_edoc_instances.

    DATA: lv_land_iso      TYPE edoc_land,
          lv_error_txt     TYPE string,
          ls_source_header TYPE edoc_src_header,
          lo_edocument     TYPE REF TO zcl_edocument_in_isu.

    CLEAR: lv_land_iso,
           lv_error_txt,
           ls_source_header,
           lo_edocument,
           et_edocument_obj.

* Country
    ls_source_header = io_source->get_header( ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'COUNTRY_CODE_SAP_TO_ISO'
      EXPORTING
        sap_code  = ls_source_header-land
      IMPORTING
        iso_code  = lv_land_iso
      EXCEPTIONS
        not_found = 1
        OTHERS    = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MESSAGE e881(b1) WITH ls_source_header-land INTO lv_error_txt.
    ENDIF.
    IF lv_land_iso <> 'IN'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    CREATE OBJECT lo_edocument 
      EXPORTING
        io_source_data = io_source
        iv_update_task = iv_update_task.

    APPEND lo_edocument TO et_edocument_obj.

  ENDMETHOD.

          2. Configure this 'Z' eDocument factory class in the view EDOFACTORYV using the transaction SM30.‚ÄØ
               Example:

Source Type‚ÄØ 

Factory Class‚ÄØ 

ISU_INVOIC‚ÄØ 

‚ÄòZ‚Äô factory class name (your factory class that you just created)‚ÄØ 

  • Create eDocument Class
    1. Create a 'Z' eDocument class by inheriting CL_EDOCUMENT_IN_EINV class.  
    2. Add the CONSTRUCTOR method to your 'Z' eDocument class to map the 'Z' eDocument IS-U class name to ms_edocument-edocument_class.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
    3. Redefine the method DETERMINE_EDOC_TYPE to assign the eDocument type.
    4. Use the table TFK003EDOC to configure eDocument type against the accounting document type

    5.  Add the class CL_EDOC_PROCESS as 'Friends' of 'Z' eDocument class.‚ÄØ
      Sample Code:  
METHOD determine_edoc_type.

    DATA: lv_blart      TYPE blart,
          ls_tfk003edoc TYPE tfk003edoc.

    CLEAR: lv_blart,
           ls_tfk003edoc.

    IF mo_source->mv_source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      lv_blart = mo_source->get_blart( ).
*      ls_tfk003edoc = me->select_tfk003edoc( iv_land = ms_edocument-land iv_blart = lv_blart ).
      DATA: l_applk TYPE tfkfbs-applk.

      CLEAR: l_applk,
             ls_tfk003edoc.

      CALL FUNCTION 'FKK_GET_APPLICATION'
        IMPORTING
          e_applk          = l_applk
        EXCEPTIONS
          no_appl_selected = 1
          OTHERS           = 2.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM tfk003edoc
          INTO ls_tfk003edoc
          WHERE land  = ms_edocument-land
            AND applk = l_applk
            AND blart = lv_blart.
      ENDIF.
      rv_edoc_type = ls_tfk003edoc-edoc_type.
    ELSE.
      rv_edoc_type = super->determine_edoc_type( ).
    ENDIF.
    ms_edocument-edoc_type = rv_edoc_type.

    determine_edoc_type_global(
      CHANGING
        cv_edoc_type = rv_edoc_type ).

  ENDMETHOD.
METHOD constructor.

  super->constructor( io_source_data                 = io_source_data
                      iv_edoc_guid                   = iv_edoc_guid
                      iv_land                        = iv_land
                      iv_generic_badi_filter_adaptor = 'ISU_INVOIC'
                      iv_update_task                 = iv_update_task ).

  ms_edocument-land                   = 'IN'.
  ms_edocument-edocument_class        = 'ZCL_EDOCUMENT_IN_ISU'.

ENDMETHOD.

  • Create Mapping Class
    1. Create a 'Z' mapping class by inheriting CL_EDOC_MAP_IN_EINV class.
      Example: ZCL_EDOC_MAP_IN_EINV_ISU
    2. Redefine the method MAP_GEN_EINVR1 of the newly created class to fill the proxy structure with utilities data.
    3. Implement the BAdI EDOC_INTERFACE_CONNECTOR (Enhancement Spot - ES_EDOCUMENT) with specific filters.
    4. Inherit the class CL_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IN_EINV_AIF and delete the interfaces in 'Z' BAdI class.‚ÄØ
    5. Redefine the method IF_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IMPL~GET_SOURCE_DATA to map the IS-U print document data to rd_source_data.
    6. Deactivate the standard BAdI enhancement implementation EI_EDOC_INTF_CONN_IN_EINV_AIF.‚ÄØ
    7.  Configure your mapping class in the view EDOMAPCLASSDETV using the transaction SM30.‚ÄØ

      Sample Code for Get Source Data  
  METHOD if_edoc_intf_conn_impl~get_source_data.

    DATA : ls_isu_invoice  TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
           lo_edocument_in TYPE REF TO zcl_edocument_in_isu,
           lo_source       TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
           ls_src_header   TYPE edoc_src_header,
           ls_source       TYPE edoc_in_gen_source,
           lv_class_name   TYPE edoc_mapping_class.

    DATA : lv_doc_header TYPE string,
           lv_doc_item   TYPE string,
           lv_t001       TYPE string,
           lv_t001z      TYPE string,
           lv_fkkvkp     TYPE string,
           lv_dfkkko     TYPE string.

    CONSTANTS: lc_document_header TYPE char15 VALUE 'DOCUMENT_HEADER'.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_doc_header>  TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_header1> TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_item>    TYPE any,
                   <fs_doc_item1>   TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001>        TYPE any,
                   <fs_t0011>       TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001z>       TYPE any,
                   <fs_t001z1>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_fkkvkp>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_fkkvkp1>     TYPE any,
                   <fs_dfkkko>      TYPE any,
                   <fs_dfkkko1>     TYPE any.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_source>    TYPE edoc_in_gen_source.

    TRY.
        CALL METHOD super->if_edoc_intf_conn_impl~get_source_data
          EXPORTING
            io_edocument   = io_edocument
          receiving
            rd_source_data = rd_source_data.

        IF io_edocument->ms_edocument-source_type = 'ISU_INVOIC'.
* Retrieve source document and map according to source type
          lo_source    = io_edocument->get_source( ).
          ls_src_header = lo_source->get_header( ).

          lo_source->get_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_isu_invoice ).

          lo_edocument_in ?= io_edocument.
          ls_source-reference-edoc_guid = lo_edocument_in->ms_edocument-edoc_guid.
          ls_source-source_header       = ls_src_header.
          ls_source-reference-edoc_guid = io_edocument->ms_edocument-edoc_guid.

          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOC_HEADER_ISU' OF STRUCTURE ls_source TO <fs_doc_header1>.
          IF <fs_doc_header1> IS ASSIGNED.
            lv_doc_header   = 'LS_SOURCE-DOC_HEADER_ISU_HU'.
            ASSIGN (lv_doc_header) TO <fs_doc_header>.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT lc_document_header OF STRUCTURE ls_isu_invoice TO <fs_doc_header>.
            <fs_doc_header1> = <fs_doc_header>.
          ENDIF.

          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOC_ITEM_ISU' OF STRUCTURE ls_source TO <fs_doc_item1>.
          IF <fs_doc_item1> IS ASSIGNED.
            lv_doc_item   = 'LS_SOURCE-DOC_ITEM_ISU_HU'.
            ASSIGN (lv_doc_item) TO <fs_doc_item>.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOCUMENT_ITEM' OF STRUCTURE ls_isu_invoice TO <fs_doc_item>.
            <fs_doc_item1> = <fs_doc_item>.
          ENDIF.

          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'FKKVKP' OF STRUCTURE ls_source TO <fs_fkkvkp1>.
          IF <fs_fkkvkp1> IS ASSIGNED.
            lv_fkkvkp   = 'LS_SOURCE-FKKVKP'.
            ASSIGN (lv_fkkvkp) TO <fs_fkkvkp>.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT 'FKKVKP' OF STRUCTURE ls_isu_invoice TO <fs_fkkvkp>.

entry.title: Modernizing SAP HR-FIN Integration in Public Institutions: Scalable Employee-Vendor Migration in S/4
entry.content:
1. Background & Objective

In SAP ECC, the Employee Vendor master is a key component for enabling travel reimbursements. Typically created via transaction PRAA, these vendor records must be transformed into Business Partners (BPs) prior to any S/4HANA upgrade using the Software Update Manager (SUM).

This transformation is not just a technical necessity; it is a critical process for ensuring financial and operational continuity post-migration. The challenge is magnified in public sector environments where Concurrent Employment is common and not fully supported by SAP‚Äôs standard programs.

The goal of this initiative was to:

  • Ensure accurate and compliant migration of Employee Vendors to Employee BPs
  • Eliminate duplicate vendor records stemming from concurrent employment
  • Design a replicable, scalable, and SAP-aligned model that can benefit other public institutions across the U.S.
  1. Mandatory Enhancements in SAP ECC

A critical consideration in the ECC-to-S/4HANA migration is the assignment of the correct Business Partner category. Employee vendors must be migrated with Category 1 (Person). Initially, Employee BPs were incorrectly created with Category 2 (Organization). To resolve this, we implemented SAP Note 3362655 ‚Äì "Mapping of the Business Partner Category as Person during Employee Vendor Migration", ensuring that the correct category was consistently applied.

With SAP S/4HANA 2021, a new Business Partner synchronization model is available via Business Function /SHCM/EE_BP_1/. In this model:

  • One BP with the Employee role represents the central person (CP)
  • One or more BPs with the Employment role represent individual contracts (PERNRs)

We utilized program /SHCM/R_EMPL_HANDLE_BPROLES to assign vendor roles to Employment BPs. However, in environments with Concurrent Employment, this standard logic assigns vendor roles to all assignments, including secondary ones‚Äîcreating duplicate vendors and risking payment errors.

To address this, we enhanced the program to exclude Employment BPs for secondary assignments from vendor role mapping. This ensures that only the main assignment is eligible for travel payments and vendor role assignment.

  1. Migration of Employee Vendors in ECC

The MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT transaction was used to migrate employee vendors (ZEMPL) into Employee Business Partners. The same number range was maintained for both the Employee Vendor and the corresponding BP to ensure traceability and consistency.

  1. Configurations after SAP S/4HANA migration and before releasing the system to users:  

a. Business Function Activation

Per SAP recommendation, business function /SHCM/EE_BP_1 is activated in S/4HANA to support the New Business partner Model.

Characteristics of the new employee business partner model
‚Ä¢ One business partner per central person with role Employee is created
‚Ä¢ Separate business partners are created for every employment (every secondary assignment)
‚Ä¢ Employment BP can have vendor or other roles assigned based on business requirement

b. Below config has been performed in the development system and then migrated along the landscape to production:

Table T77SO:

For HRALX-ESUBG=AB, we need to maintain the number range. Please see below section

c. Define Number Ranges

IMG-Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Number Ranges and Groupings.

d. Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges

IMG-Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner-> Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges.

Maintained AB number range:

e. Create Number Ranges for Vendor Accounts

IMG->Financial Accounting->Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable->Supplier Accounts->Master Data->Preparations for Creating Supplier Master Data-> Create Number Ranges for Vendor Accounts

f. Assign Number Ranges to Vendor Account Groups

IMG->Financial Accounting->Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable->Supplier Accounts->Master Data->Preparations for Creating Supplier Master Data-> Assign Number Ranges to Vendor Account Groups

Assign AB Number range to ZEMPL account group

g. Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Vendor

IMG Path- Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Field Assignment for Vendor Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Vendor

h. Define Number Assignment for Direction Vendor to BP

IMG Path- Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Field Assignment for Vendor Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction Vendor to BP

i. Define Address Types

Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Basic Settings->Address Determination->Define Address Types

Maintain HCM001 & HCM003

  • HCM001 Employee Private Address
  • HCM003 Address of Main Employment

j. Define Identification Types

Cross-Application Components->SAP Business Partner->Business Partner->Basic Settings ->Identification Numbers->Define Identification Types

Maintain HCM001, HCM032 and HCM033

  • HCM032 Personnel Number (Main Employment)
  • HCM033 Personnel Number (Employment)

 

k. Define BP Roles

IMG->Cross-Application Components ->SAP Business Partner ->Business Partner ->Basic Settings ->Define BP Roles.

 

l. Define Reconciliation Accounts for Employees in Role FI Supplier

IMG->Integration with Other SAP Components->Integration with SAP Success Factors (Employee Central)-> Define Reconciliation Accounts for Employees in Role FI Supplier.

m. PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC

Launch SM30 and enter table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC, also create a reference vendor in the development client and later this needs to be maintained in each client.

  1. Initial HR Sync in SAP S/4HANA

This report /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_EMPL_SINGLE must be executed before releasing the system to the users. This report is executed for all active and inactive employees:

  1. For pernrs with single employment- This report will create two BPs, one BP with employee role and another BP with employment role. 
  2. For pernrs with multiple employment- This report will create one BP with employee role and one or more employment role (for each secondary assignment, an employment BP will be created).  Post S/4HANA Employee Sync Jobs

After SAP S/4HANA GO-Live, report /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_FROM_EMPL must be scheduled in background. This report must run daily in production.

Note: when a new employee record is created, immediately system creates an employee BP and employment BP if the effective date = systems date. If the effective date is in future, this job /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_FROM_EMPL creates employee BP and employment BP based on effective date. Hence, it is essential to run this job daily.

  1. /SHCM/R_EMPL_HDLE_BPRLES_DELTA-Vendor Role Job

This job adds a vendor role-FLVN00 to an employment BP. This report reads the data from table-/SHCM/D_RLE_SYNC. This report should run in production on daily basis.

Important Note: Program /SHCM/R_EMPL_HANDLE_BPROLES also adds vendor role to selected Pernrs with employment BP. This program has a selection screen to enter the Pernr. This program can be executed on an exceptional basis. We have modified this program to skip the vendor role addition for secondary assignments (as mentioned earlier).

8. Enhancements in /SHCM/R_EMPL_HDLE_BPRLES_DELTA

Enhancement #1: If the report is mistakenly executed without a variant, this report can add vendor role to all employment BPs, hence an enhancement is added to run this job with Last sync date. An error message will be displayed to the users if this report is executed without Last sync date.

Enhancement#2: Since this report adds a vendor role to secondary assignment, an enhancement is needed to prevent the vendor role creation for secondary assignment. If a pernr in the table -/SHCM/D_RLE_SYNC is a secondary assignment, the enhancement will skip that pernr and vendor role will not be added.

Enhancement #3: An enhancement is done to modify the payment method and house bank information in employee vendor based on HR payment method and Bank information.

  1. Employee Business Partner Overview Report

The report /SHCM/R_EE_BP_RELATION_OVW (T.code-/SHCM/EE_BP_RLTN) provides a relationship between User, employee BP, employment BP and vendor #. This report can be executed with Pernr or Business Partner # or User ID.

  1. Troubleshooting Tips:
    1. Table BUT000- this table provides creation and modifications date and time stamp for employee BP and employment BP.
    2. SLG1 log to check all BP creation errors

Conclusion

This document demonstrates a complete, end-to-end strategy for employee vendor migration during SAP S/4HANA implementation. Through custom enhancements and targeted configuration, we aligned the migration with SAP best practices while addressing unique institutional needs such as Concurrent Employment.

The solution is scalable and applicable to other U.S.-based public institutions‚Äîensuring reliable vendor synchronization, accurate travel payments, and reduced duplication in a highly regulated environment.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

  • Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment
  • Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates
  • Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER
  • Simplified Data Integration
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Catena-X Certification
  • SAP Innovation Award Wins: Harting and Matsumoto Precision
  • Customer Success Story: DMK
  • SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

 

Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment

When integrating SAP Sustainability Footprint Management with various SAP systems, you often face a data challenge: Your warehouse in one SAP solution might be a facility in another or even a resource elsewhere. This inconsistency complicates footprint calculations, energy flow modeling, and linking environmental results to financials.

To address this and streamline and simplify the management of location data, we released the new Manage Locations application. This app serves as a single source for managing all locations, regardless of origin or business context. It addresses the need to reconcile and correlate locations that may have different semantics across multiple SAP solutions. With this new app you can:

  • View and manage all locations in one consolidated interface
  • Manually create locations or view those imported from other SAP modules
  • Easily distinguish between manually created and imported locations via the user interface
  • Navigate via links between imported location records and their corresponding system-generated system entries

Alternatively to replicating locations from source systems or creating them manually, you can upload location information via Excel files in the Import Master Data app. When importing, the software automatically generates corresponding location records that appear in the Manage Locations app ‚Äì ensuring no duplicated or orphaned records. The locations itself are categorized into different location types, adding business context: Meter, Process Infrastructure, and Facility. Imported locations are automatically mapped to one of these three types. If a location type doesn‚Äôt match, it defaults to Facility. For modeling energy flows, you can now use these harmonized locations and resources as elements in your models. Hence, the creation of meters, process infrastructures, and facilities within the Model Energy Flows app is now managed exclusively via the new Manage Locations app ‚Äì ensuring data consistency across apps.

Another major improvement is the possibility to assign cost centers for financial transparency and connecting carbon footprint results directly with your financial reporting. These assignments are time-dependent, ensuring correct mapping for each period. After calculating your organizational footprint, the Manage Footprint Results app shows the active cost center for that location ‚Äì specifically, the cost center that is valid as of the calculation period‚Äôs start date, which is important if multiple cost centers are assigned to the location. Besides locations, cost centers can now also be assigned to energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. This enables better tracking of spending related to energy use and maintenance, helping to analyze and manage energy costs more effectively.

Click the picture to start the video:

Manage Locations App (Click to start video)

To summarize, these enhancements bring you a centralized, consistent interface for all location data with improved usability and a simplified integration across various SAP systems. The flexible cost center assignment enables the linkage of environmental data to financial entities. This empowers smarter and holistic decision-making in sustainability management, moving further along the journey towards ledger-based carbon accounting with SAP Green Ledger. For all details, see Manage Locations on SAP Help.

 

Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates

A common challenge for calculating Scope 1 and 2 emissions is the timely availability of energy bills needed for accurately recording energy consumption. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management addresses this by introducing more flexibility in how energy data can be captured. Now, when creating energy sources, you can select your preferred method for recording energy consumption, with the two available options:

  • Actual Consumption from Energy Bills: Enter the actual quantities consumed as detailed on your energy bills (the most accurate method).
  • Estimates via Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates: Add up amounts based on assigned meter readings and planned energy consumption rates, which allows you to work with estimates when bills are unavailable.

Select Recording of Energy Consumption

This new functionality isn‚Äôt limited to newly created energy sources. You can apply it to existing ones as well. However, it‚Äôs important to note that updating an energy source with this new logic doesn‚Äôt automatically trigger updates across all footprint inventories. If you edit the inventories that reference the updated energy source in their energy flow models, the system will recalculate using the newly selected consumption recording logic.

This release gives you the flexibility to maintain complete and more timely energy consumption records, improving the reliability of your sustainability data even when actual energy bills are delayed or not available at all. For more information, see the Energy Sources section under Model Energy Flows.

 

Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER

For calculating carbon footprints with no actual supplier or provider data available, it‚Äôs crucial to have access to reliable industry average data from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management provides you with the flexibility to upload respective data from any source into the Manage Emission Factors app. To simplify the setup for you and reduce manual efforts, we now added new default content, available for mapping your activities for calculating the respective footprints.

The data from UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (UK DEFRA) includes emission factors for energy use, water consumption, waste disposal, recycling, and transport activities. There are datasets available for the years 2015 to 2024.

EMBER, an independent energy think tank, provides emission factors for electricity generation for over 200 geographies. The datasets comprise the years 2015 to 2023.

Click the picture to start the video:

Default Emission Factors in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Click to start video)

With those enhancements, you have access to additional reliable and diverse data sources for better environmental impact analysis and decision-making. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data.

This new content complements the datasets from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) which were already added last year. And for the second half year we plan to add even more pre-configured emission factors from additional sources, further enhancing your carbon footprint calculation. The addition of emission factors was also one of the highest voted items on SAP Influence, requested by several customers and partners. Thanks to your valuable feedback, we‚Äôre constantly improving our product.

 

Simplified Data Integration

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduced significant enhancements to how sustainability data is imported and managed, making processes more simple, efficient, and user-friendly. The tool leverages the sustainability data integration service to streamline data import from SAP systems, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Environment, Health and Safety Management. This update eliminates many manual steps and unifies the process across systems. All changes are reflected in the updated SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Implementation Guide on SAP Help Portal.

With those enhancements, we‚Äôre also introducing the Manage Replications application. This new app allows you to configure and manage the replication of master data objects, such as products or suppliers, from multiple integrated SAP systems. Once replication is initiated through this app, imported data becomes visible in the Import Master Data app, simplifying subsequent data management tasks. The key benefits for you are:

  • Multi-source replication: Import master data from various source systems (for example fetch Products from SAP S/4HANA and Suppliers from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  • Centralized management: Oversee and control all data replications from one place.
  • Improved data consistency: Ensures data is harmonized and consistent, provided the correct source systems are chosen for each data object.
  • Filter records: For some of the entities, like Products, you can filter the source data objects so only the ones which are relevant in your footprint calculation are replicated.

To use the Manage Replications app, users must be manually assigned the roles: SUS_Replication_Viewer or SUS_Replication_Expert. Find further information as well as all details on the new app in SAP Help: Manage Replications.

Manage Replications App

For existing customers, the following changes are required:

  • Switch to Manage Replications App: The previous method of importing master data directly within the Import Master Data app is discontinued for integrated source systems. The Import button has been removed, and all such imports must now be managed through the new Manage Replications app.
  • SAP EHS Management Integration: All emissions management activities and locations must now be imported via the Manage Replications app.
  • Replication Details: When replicating Suppliers or Emission Management Activities, each replication now performs a complete import ‚Äì incremental or delta updates are no longer supported for these entities.

Those updates vastly improve the efficiency and governance of sustainability data management within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, offering you a more powerful, secure, and streamlined experience when handling master data from multiple integrated sources.

 

Other Release Highlights

The Monitor Plausibility Checks app displays reference details of the item, period, and measure value used as the baseline for creating relative plausibility alerts. This helps you assess how much actual results deviate from expected calculations. For more information, see Monitor Plausibility Checks. This is also a feature that was implemented after numerous customers requested it via SAP Influence.

A new Generate Records button in the Manage Purchased Products Footprints app allows you to manually generate records for purchased products and product groups that lack footprints. Progress is displayed during record generation, and users are notified if records need to be regenerated due to data updates, ensuring accuracy and control. Additionally, the UI in the related tabs now labels the AI-assisted mapping button as Generate Mappings Using AI. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more details.

We achieved significant performance improvements in cycle calculations, where a process's output becomes its own input. Previously, the runtime increased with the cycle's complexity. Now, calculations are done in-memory rather than relying on database access, greatly reducing calculation time and improving user efficiency.

SAP now offers real-time machine translation for documentation on the SAP Help Portal, including SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This increases the number of available languages, improving accessibility and availability of product information for users worldwide.

To help you with onboarding and using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we‚Äôre also constantly enhancing the product documentation on SAP Help. In the previous quarter, this included the following topics:

  • Energy carrier assignment per internal service confirmation: The new topic in the Energy Distribution Scenarios section explains two different methods for assigning energy to production documents using data from internal service confirmations, see Energy Carrier Assignment per Internal Service Confirmation.
  • Modeling consistent energy flows: Useful guidance on using energy elements in flow models and explanations on how different components are connected, see Modeling Consistent Energy Flows.
  • Energy distribution scenarios: The updated explanation details how energy consumption and distribution are modeled via the energy flows, using planned rates, meter data, or both, see Energy Distribution Scenarios.
  • Importing master data for Products using file upload: An example explains how to enter data for quantity conversions and quantity dimensions, see the section Example: Quantity Conversions and Dimensions in Products.
  • Data Inconsistencies: Guidelines on addressing these issues, see Business Transaction Data Consistency for details.
  • Delete imported business transaction data: More details on how to handle this process, see Deleting Business Transaction Data.

 

Catena-X Certification

In Q2, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management successfully was Catena-X certified by Cofinity-X, as the first carbon calculation software to receive this certification. Catena-X is the automotive industry‚Äôs open, collaborative data ecosystem, designed to facilitate secure and standardized data exchange across the entire value chain. With this certification, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management meets the rigorous calculation, interoperability, and data sovereignty standards required by Catena-X, enabling customers to seamlessly calculate and share trustworthy carbon footprint and sustainability data with partners, suppliers, and customers in the ecosystem. This not only supports regulatory and customer-driven transparency requirements but also paves the way for scalable decarbonization efforts in the automotive industry and beyond. By aligning with Catena-X, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management empowers organizations to participate confidently in cross-company sustainability initiatives within a rapidly evolving digital value network. With the integration to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, carbon footprint data can be exchanged automatically and seamlessly.

 

Innovation Award Wins

We‚Äôre very proud to announce that two of our SAP Sustainability Footprint Management customers won the SAP Innovation Award 2025 in the Sustainability Hero category: Harting Technology Group and Matsumoto Precision!

Faced with the challenge of calculating carbon footprints for over 100,000 products across 14 factories, HARTING Technology Group needed a scalable, integrated solution. By becoming an early pilot customer of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, HARTING automated emissions tracking and achieved one-click carbon footprint calculations for 13,000 products ‚Äì replacing a manual, time-consuming process. The solution, now live in three factories and expanding to all 14 by 2026, enables real-time, granular CO‚ÇÇ data that supports HARTING‚Äôs ‚ÄúGreenLine‚Äù product label and helps meet stringent EU regulations like the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Digital Product Passport. Thanks to this innovation, HARTING can now report that 85% of its packaging materials are recycled, and it has a clear path to achieving net-zero operations by 2030. This collaboration with SAP not only enhances transparency and compliance but also gives HARTING a competitive edge in customer bids ‚Äì proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand. Read the whole story here: HARTING - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

To address the growing demand for carbon transparency and operational efficiency, Matsumoto Precision implemented SAP S/4HANA alongside SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This combination gave the company real-time visibility into both product-level carbon emissions and profitability. With this data-driven approach, Matsumoto Precision was able to reduce its annual CO‚ÇÇ emissions by 400 tons, increase productivity by 30 percent, and improve its operating profit margin by 3 percent. The factory now runs entirely on renewable energy, with on-site solar generation covering a significant portion of its needs. The implementation also empowered employees with real-time insights, leading to better decision-making and increased job satisfaction. Customers now receive verified carbon footprint data for each product, enhancing trust and supporting their own sustainability goals. In collaboration with Accenture, Matsumoto Precision even developed a generative AI tool that automates lifecycle flow diagrams, significantly reducing manual effort and streamlining emissions reporting. As CEO Toshitada Matsumoto put it, ‚ÄúWith SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we make smarter, greener decisions while tracking and visualizing CO‚ÇÇ emissions for each product. And with this clarity, we can enhance our brand value.‚Äù Matsumoto Precision‚Äôs journey is a compelling example of how small and mid-sized manufacturers can lead the way in sustainable innovation by embedding carbon intelligence into every layer of their operations. Read the full story here: Matsumoto Precision Co., Ltd. - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

 

Customer Success Story: DMK

Germany‚Äôs largest dairy cooperative, DMK Deutsches Milchkontor GmbH, is leading the way in sustainable food production. Processing over 5.3 billion kilograms of milk annually, DMK is committed to reducing its environmental impact across the value chain. With ambitious climate goals ‚Äì including a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030 ‚Äì DMK turned to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to bring transparency and precision to its carbon accounting.

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, DMK transformed how it calculates and manages product-level emissions. The solution enabled the company to move beyond industry averages and instead use granular, actual data to assess the carbon footprint of its milk-based products. This shift provided DMK with unprecedented transparency and accuracy, particularly in understanding and reporting Scope 3 emissions from its upstream value chain, such as milk production and transportation.

The digitalization of carbon footprint management not only helped DMK meet regulatory requirements but also strengthened its ability to respond to customer demands for credible, verifiable sustainability metrics. With SAP‚Äôs expert support and a tailored pilot program, DMK integrated emissions data directly into its product lifecycle, enabling more strategic decision-making and targeted decarbonization efforts.

This collaboration has positioned DMK as a leader in sustainable dairy production, demonstrating how digital tools can drive real progress toward climate goals while enhancing trust and transparency across the value chain. Read the full story here: DMK: Identifying the carbon footprint of milk-based products on the way to decarbonizing the value chain.

 

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP‚Äôs commitment to sustainability is integrated into its core mission of improving economic, social, and environmental outcomes while respecting planetary and human rights boundaries. SAP is actively using its own sustainability software solutions to meet environmental and social goals, demonstrating an ‚ÄúSAP runs SAP‚Äù and ‚Äúcustomer zero‚Äù approach. By implementing tools like SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management within its operations, SAP treats sustainability management with the same rigor as financial reporting.

As a user, SAP faces challenges similar to its clients: collecting and managing large volumes of sustainability data, ensuring compliance with evolving regulations, and integrating data systems across the organization and supply chain. By implementing its sustainability solutions and continuously refining them through hands-on experience, SAP gains valuable insights that help improve its products for clients. Key lessons from their internal adoption include: ensuring consistent emissions data collection, grounding projects within governance frameworks, expanding focus beyond carbon to other environmental factors, and establishing a multi-layer data architecture for effective collection, processing, and reporting. The rollout of these systems is iterative, enabling refinement and adaptation‚Äîespecially important as regulatory requirements change, such as the new EU Omnibus package. Overall, SAP aims to provide actionable sustainability insights, streamline ESG reporting, and drive both internal and customer progress toward measurable sustainability outcomes. To learn more, read the news article from Matthias Medert, SAP‚Äôs global head of Sustainability: SAP Runs Its Own Solutions for Sustainability Goals.

A central piece of the SAP runs SAP Sustainability IT architecture is SAP Sustainability Footprint Management:

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability - IT Architecture

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP has created a centralized and integrated platform to collect and calculate its corporate carbon emissions. The ambition is clear: to achieve full coverage of SAP‚Äôs carbon footprint through automated data collection and calculation. The software is much more than just a reporting tool, it acts as a central hub for emissions data, feeding into other SAP sustainability solutions such as the SAP Green Ledger, the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and various internal systems. This enables comprehensive environmental impact analysis and supports regulatory compliance, while also informing strategic business decisions. Currently, SAP has already validated around 50% of its corporate carbon footprint within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. The journey hasn‚Äôt been without challenges. At the outset, SAP faced difficulties in gathering and harmonizing data from multiple sources, each managed by different internal teams. Looking ahead, SAP aims to expand the system‚Äôs coverage to 100% of its corporate carbon footprint (excluding downstream emissions) before the planned business go-live in Q3. All of this is being achieved through a continuous co-innovation process with SAP‚Äôs sustainability product engineering teams, demonstrating how SAP isn‚Äôt only building tools for others but also using them to lead by example. entry.title: The AI Stack Is Ready ‚Äî Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology
entry.content:
The Challenge No Longer Is Technology

Having worked hands-on with enterprise software for close to three decades, I‚Äôve seen countless technology shifts ‚Äî some promising incremental gains, others causing deep industry disruption. But none of them ‚Äî none ‚Äî have matured as quickly and as loudly as GenAI.

 

We are no longer in the ‚Äúwait and see‚Äù phase. The stack is here. The APIs are mature. The building blocks ‚Äî from LLMs to vector databases and orchestration frameworks ‚Äî are all operational. There‚Äôs no question that we now have the technological backbone to deliver GenAI-enabled solutions across practically any business function.

Even common criticisms like hallucinations are being actively addressed. With test-time compute techniques ‚Äî like prompt engineering, function calling, retrieval-augmented generation, and tool usage ‚Äî hallucinations are kept at bay, quality radically increases, and results become not only reliable but robust. These advances prove a critical point: most GenAI objectives are technically attainable today.

Sure, the LLMs will continue to evolve, improving in reasoning and domain specialization. But they are already good enough to be effectively leveraged in real-world workflows ‚Äî assuming the right usage patterns, guardrails, and integration strategies are in place.

So if tech is no longer the bottleneck‚Ä¶ what is?

 

The Real Challenge: Ideas and Governance

Once upon a time, our hardest problem was figuring out how to make the tech work. Today, the hardest problem is figuring out what to build, how to deploy it responsibly, and how to scale and govern it across a rapidly shifting organizational landscape.

Think about it: spinning up a chatbot with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is no longer a moonshot. Hooking up a vector DB to your internal documents, embedding GenAI into Fiori apps or ABAP logic, orchestrating workflows with agentic logic ‚Äî this is all doable. But what‚Äôs much harder is identifying high-value, sustainable use cases and creating a framework that doesn‚Äôt devolve into chaos as teams independently launch proof-of-concepts without strategy or alignment.

 

Why Ideation Matters More Than Ever

Let‚Äôs be honest: the biggest risk with GenAI today isn‚Äôt that the models don‚Äôt work ‚Äî it‚Äôs that either we‚Äôre not building enough or we‚Äôre building too much, too fast, and too randomly. Every team spins up their own assistant. Use cases are vague. Nothing talks to each other. No reuse. No alignment. That‚Äôs not innovation ‚Äî that‚Äôs chaos.

 

We‚Äôve moved past the stage where the question is ‚ÄúCan we build this?‚Äù

Now it‚Äôs about ‚ÄúShould we build it?‚Äù

And even more importantly: ‚ÄúHow do we keep it working well over time?‚Äù

 

This is why ideation can‚Äôt just be a sticky note exercise or a quick prompt storming session in ChatGPT. We have to treat it with the same rigor we apply to architecture. That means thinking about the business context, designing for scale, and planning for long-term sustainability ‚Äî not just the MVP.

And here‚Äôs where the tough questions start to pop up ‚Äî the ones we should be asking upfront:

  • Are we using the most effective language model from a quality vs. cost perspective?
  • Are we selecting the fastest possible model for latency-sensitive workflows? (If you‚Äôre doing multi-agent interactions, speed matters a lot.)
  • How is the quality of the responses behaving over time? Are we tracking degradation or drift?
  • What‚Äôs our strategy for testing newer LLMs as they come out? Should we switch? If so, how do we regression test across use cases without breaking things?
  • As our knowledge base grows, are we managing it properly? Is it staying focused, or are we bloating it with irrelevant context that just confuses the model?

These aren‚Äôt just technical questions. These are product and platform questions. And unless we ask them early ‚Äî during ideation ‚Äî we risk building solutions that are impressive in a demo but fragile, expensive, or completely unmaintainable in production.

Ideation today needs to account for all of this. It‚Äôs not just about dreaming big ‚Äî it‚Äôs about designing smart.

 

Governance: From One-Off Demos to Scalable Systems

Without governance, GenAI becomes a set of disconnected experiments. With governance, it becomes an enabler of business-wide transformation.

This governance isn‚Äôt just about policies or committees. It‚Äôs about having:

  • Reusable components (tools, prompts, agents)
  • Common platforms (secured access to LLMs, retrievers, memory)
  • Evaluation metrics (accuracy, drift, hallucination tracking)
  • Ownership models (who builds, who maintains, who retrains)

 

Organizations that don‚Äôt invest here will be stuck in demo land. Those that do? They‚Äôll build AI capabilities into their operational DNA ‚Äî from support, finance, and HR to production and logistics.

 

FinOps: The Overlooked Layer of GenAI Operations

Another area that absolutely needs attention is FinOps ‚Äî because GenAI might be easy to spin up, but it can get expensive fast.

Where are we spending the most? Are the solutions optimized from a cost perspective, or are we overpaying for high-end models when cheaper alternatives would do the job? And more importantly, how do we split the overall bill across different teams or functions using different LLM providers?

If multiple agents are running on different models ‚Äî OpenAI for one workflow, Mistral or Claude for another ‚Äî how do we assign those costs back to the right cost centers? Who‚Äôs consuming what? Are we operating in a user-payer model? Or is everything being lumped into a single invoice no one can untangle?

These questions need to be addressed before GenAI gets deeply embedded into everyday operations. Without visibility and accountability, you risk not only spiraling costs but also poor architectural decisions driven by unclear usage patterns.

FinOps isn‚Äôt just finance‚Äôs problem ‚Äî it‚Äôs part of good governance.

 

The Role of Architects and Tech Leaders

This is where it gets personal for me.

As someone who‚Äôs been on the architecture side of SAP, building custom solutions for large enterprises, I see a massive opportunity ‚Äî and responsibility. Our role as architects and tech leaders is evolving.

We‚Äôre not just evaluating frameworks and drawing diagrams anymore. We‚Äôre setting the tone for AI readiness. We‚Äôre defining guardrails, pushing for smart reusability, and fostering the right kind of innovation ‚Äî not the ‚Äúone demo per team‚Äù variety, but the kind that results in sustainable business improvement.

 

So‚Ä¶ Are You Ready

You don‚Äôt need to wait for the perfect model or the next framework release. The AI stack is ready. The frontier now is not technical ‚Äî it‚Äôs organizational.

  • If you‚Äôre a builder: build with intent.
  • If you‚Äôre a strategist: align use cases with value.
  • If you‚Äôre a leader: create clarity and structure.

Because in the GenAI era, the best ideas ‚Äî not the best tech ‚Äî will win.

entry.title: Include released successor objects from "cloudification repo" in your ABAP custom code migration
entry.content:
Many SAP customers are currently in the phase of migrating their SAP ERP systems to S/4HANA. For those who choose a brownfield or bluefield approach the old ERP system is converted and the customers extensions and own applications (Z* objects) become part of the new system.

Then, the process of Custom Code Adaptation kicks in where the ERP functionality is analyzed and corrected in a way that the objects run again in S/4HANA. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-the-abap-custom-code-migration-process/bc-p/14049622 or https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-system-conversion-custom-code-adaptation-process/ba-p/13337309 for more details.

The custom code correction process can be time consuming and challenging depending on the size and complexity of the original ERP system. A big part of the custom code objects will be touched. The basis for the checks and corrections is the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) with the check variant for S/4HANA (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023).

In case the customer wants to move functionality to SAP BTP ABAP or the S/4HANA (public) Cloud versions it is not sufficient to make the old ERP code just S/4HANA ready. The cloud versions have a heavily restricted set of the ABAP language (so called language version 5 ) and furthermore access to SAP standard objects is allowed to (relatively few) released objects only. For instance, you must not use the MARA table to read materials but the I_PRODUCT CDS. This information is stored in the so called cloudification repository (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-check-your-custom-code-for-abap-cloud/ba-p/13567124 ) which is regularly updated. (See https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc for the Raw data).

It contains as well successor information for some of the old ERP objects in particular for the data base tables which makes it particularly interesting for the custom code migration process. See note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3284711 for installation of the according ATC check / check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)"  in releases before 2023 FP 3.

The idea is now to use the officially released successors for the objects which need to be corrected anyway during the migration ERP -> S/4HANA.

A (simple) example: When accessing table SKA1 corrections could be necessary because of the new account type attributes e.g. GLACCOUNT_TYPE in S/4; secondary cost elements are saved now as well. This is found by the S4HANA_READINESS_2023. The same access is found by the "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" check as well:

The solution to solve both issues is to check if secondary cost elements are concerned and to follow the recommendation in the finding. In the correction the successor object (DDLS I_GLACCOUNTINCHARTOFACCOUNTS) should be used directly:

 

This combination approach makes a part of the own developments "cloud ready" and "S/4HANA ready" at the same time without a big additional effort. And anyway, it is better for upgrade stability to use officially released objects!

Here are 3 possible approaches to achieve this:

Approach 1: Out of the box: Combined Check

Create a Z ATC Check variant and select the checks from S4HANA_READINESS* and the check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" . The easiest would be to copy S4HANA_READINESS* and then to select in the maintenance of the check variants (via transaction /nSCI):

 

 

Once you run the check you will see the result as in this example:

 

The findings from the combined check contain already all needed information but there are two shortcomings: the list contains many irrelevant entries; not all check categories (only when the successor is defined) nor all findings are relevant in the context of S/4HANA custom code adoption (e.g. Successor I_COUNTRY for T005 table doesn‚Äôt solve a Custom Code Migration issue).

Approach 2: Add information from Cloudification Repo manually

Instead of a combined check variant the successor information could be added via Excel / VLOOKUP (SVERWEIS in German) as well using these steps:

  1. Run the standard ATC check for Custom Code Analysis (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023)
  2. Download the detailed list from ATC to Excel (include in any case the field reference object / Referenzobjekt)
  3. Download the cloudification repo from here https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc/blob/main/src/objectReleaseInfoLatest.csv
  4. Open the data in Excel and copy the sheet to your original excel in a new tab
  5. Add a new column to the first tab from ATC data and combine the data via VLOOKUP: find a possible successor objects in the released objects for the reference objects

A possible result could look like this:

 

I added an example excel for convenience reasons to Github here: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc/blob/main/ATC_S4HANA_CLOUDIF_REPO_EXAMPLE.xlsx 

Then, when processing the ATC findings, the successor objects from Excel can be used directly in the corrections.

Approach 3: Using a custom enhancement to the SAP ATC S/4HANA: Released objects as additional information

In order to avoid the manual Excel steps and to have a lean combined list of the relevant findings only there is also the possibility to enhance the "additional information" section via an implicit enhancement or via another copy of the standard check classes in the S/4HANA Custom Code area. If you decide for the enhancement you can use the methode GET_DETAIL_FROM_DATA_BUFFER  from the central utility class CL_CI_S4H_COMMON and add the successor object information there.

The result is that if there is the successor object available it will be put to the Additional Information Section of the findings as shows the following  example:

 

 

There is an example version on Github for this as well: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc 

Now the existing ATC S4HANA readiness check is enhanced by the new released object information such as that you can directly correct the old ERP object reference and replace it by the latest officially released SAP cloud ready object!

entry.title: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
I am writing this blog for publishing on the SAP Community, focused on SAP HANA Performance Optimization. It's structured to be informative, experience-driven, and valuable to a technical audience.

SAP HANA is known for its lightning-fast in-memory computing power, but like any high-performance engine, it requires Parameters tuning, Maintenance, and optimization to ensure it's running at its peak. Whether you're an SAP Basis Consultant, HANA Admin, or someone involved in performance analysis, this guide will walk you through proven techniques and practical tips that have worked in real-world SAP projects. HANA Parameters Tuning required in case of Migration, Implementation Projects as well as Support AMS Project.

When we are migrated to SAP HANA or Installing New Hana Database, all parameters are default parameters which may not perform as per your requirement or as per your landscape So we need to tune those parameters for system performance. SAP HANA parameter tuning for performance optimization involves configuring various system settings to maximize efficiency. Key areas include data modeling, load optimization, query optimization, and utilizing features like partitioning and columnar storage. Fine-tuning these parameters can significantly impact data processing speed, memory usage, and overall system responsiveness

Why HANA Performance Optimization Matters ?

In an enterprise environment, poor performance can impact business processes, reporting speed, and even downstream applications. Optimizing HANA ensures:

  • Faster analytics and reporting
  • Better end-user experience
  • Reduced infrastructure costs
  • Longer hardware lifecycle

 SAP S/4HANA End-to-End Performance Overview

SAP S/4HANA Architecture consist of 3-tiers, a SAP Fiori UI5 frontend, an SAP S/4HANA ABAP backend and a SAP HANA database

Database and ABAP processing times are two primary components of ABAP response time. Effects of pushing code to SAP HANA changes standard metrics of ABAP and database time as well as the common SAP R/3  and S/4 standard of 1 second per Dialog step.

Some SAP HANA features and ABAP coding that contribute to backend response times.

  • Core Data Services (CDS)
  • ABAP Managed Database Procedures
  • Compatibility views
  • Parallel processing in SAP HANA
  • Columnar in-memory database

End-to-End performance of an SAP S/4HANA system is spread across 4 layers: SAP Fiori UI, SAP S/4HANA  ABAP layer, CDS views and SAP HANA

Below are 11 Points need to perform for HANA Performance Optimization.

1. Monitor Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

Start with regular monitoring of essential KPIs:

Both tools provide dashboards to analyze:

  • Memory load and footprint
  • Active sessions and threads
  • Expensive SQL statements
  • Alerts (CPU, Disk, Memory, column unloads)

Tip: Configure alerting thresholds to get notified before performance degrades.

3. Data Volume Management (DVM)

Large tables or outdated data can slow down performance.

  • Archive or purge old data
  • Split large tables into partitions
  • Use RSDA_DATA_SELECT or DBACOCKPIT to find large table

5. Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA.

Run the HANA_Configuration_Parameters_1.00.90+ or HANA_Configuration_Parameters_2.00.040+.txt script, which is maintained in SAP note 1969700 SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA (below is a sample output) , Do Mini Checks in System and check all parameters and set SAP recommended parameters accordingly.

Additional Info

  • These checks can be executed on the SYSTEMDB and on each Tenant DB (for Hana 2.0) - but are particularly important for the Tenant DB's
  • Each Tenant DB can have different parameter values set, depending on each customer requirement
  • It is recommended that each Tenant has these best practice parameter values in place before productive use starts i.e. run these checks immediately after installation or upgrade, implement parameter value recommendations and test that these meet your business requirements
  • The output of the script will only show Hana parameters which are not currently set as per best practice recommendations
  • It will give recommended parameter value settings and note references on the particular parameter/topic area
  • In the P (Priority) column, you can see the most critical parameters to be set - 1 has highest priority
  • It will give actual SQL commands (ALTER statements) to set the parameter to the required value
  • And also an UNDO_COMMAND should you need to revert the parameter
  • If opening a support case with SAP Technical Support, providing the output of this parameter check will help to speed up the analysis
  • Check out the SAP HANA Configuration Parameter Reference: Index guide as per your HANA revision
  • In List SAP also provides Commands to modify Parameters. Just need to run those commands at SQL in HANA Cockpit or Studio.

7. OS and Infrastructure Checks

  • Ensure proper NUMA configuration
  • Keep kernel and firmware updated

  • Monitor swap usage: HANA hates swapping!

 9. Smart Delta Merge Strategy

Delta merges can cause spikes in memory and CPU.

  • Check M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS regularly
  • Avoid frequent merges on volatile tables
  • Automate delta merge scheduling for off-peak times

Tip: Always back up config and consult SAP notes before changing parameters.

To keep control of the delta merge we keep our table enable AUTOMERGE but in the data loading time we keep it into disable auto merge and enable smart merge for large volume tables.

Auto Merge :  HANA keeps a compressed ‚Äúmain‚Äù store of column tables and an uncompressed ‚Äúdelta‚Äù store, for new items. Periodically, a process called mergedog combines the two in a DELTA MERGE process. Sometimes however your tables may not be configured to automerge (you can issue ALTER TABLE table name ENABLE AUTOMERGE), and occasionally merged fails and you have to restart HANA. This can cause the delta store to become very large, and because it is uncompressed, this is a big issue if you don‚Äôt have much RAM.

SAP regularly publishes SAP HANA performance-related notes. Some helpful ones include:

  • SAP Note 1999997 ‚Äì SAP HANA Troubleshooting Guide (FAQ: SAP HANA Memory)
  • SAP Note 2399079 ‚Äì Elimination of hdbparam in HANA 2

  • Clean up old logs and trace files.
  • Reclaim memory, data volume and logs (ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOGS, MEMORY, DATAVOLUME)
  • Remove obsolete backups from disk

 Conclusion

SAP HANA is a powerful platform, but like any high-performance machine, it needs care and attention. By combining smart monitoring, regular analysis, and data management best practices, you can keep your system running efficiently and support your business-critical operations smoothly.
